description: The Reebok Engine A does not disappoint. If you can get the fit right, the performance feels fantastic.
Kudos to Reebok for moving in the right direction with the Engine A. I like the comfort, and the traction plays well on clean courts.
The Reebok Engine A is a solid performer, especially for a comeback model. I like the cushioning, and the traction is consistent.
The traction picks up dust quickly, but the performance plays well if you wipe regularly.
On a clean court, the traction performs nicely. My only problem is the dust pickup. I had to wipe often.
Traction works well for me. The performance is consistent.
I like the tough top-loaded shank and the Energy Return System foam. The shock absorption is impressive, and there's a bit of bounce.
I like the insole, and the heel is plush. The ERS foam provides plenty of impact protection. I wish it were bouncier, though.
The cushioning feels delicious. It offers softness, bounce, and impact protection.
The upper is a lot of TPU mesh and panelling, and the shoe heats up a lot. However, I love the comfort.

The shoe is heavier than average but lighter than expected. The materials are thinner and softer in hand, and the breathability is decent.
Heel slippage is mild, but the base is stable.
Heel containment and lockdown are good but not excellent. There's room for improvement. However, balance is a strength.

The fit is the biggest crux of the shoe. They feel oversized. Need to go down a size to get a good fit.

Even without the $40 price decrease, I thought the NXXT Gen outperformed the XX on court. They kept the great combo zoom setup, but made a few changes around it. The thick, soft cushlon was swapped out for a firmer phylon, greatly increasing courtfeel while still providing good impact protection. The bottom loaded CF shank was swapped out for a top loaded TPE shank, but still gives plenty of return and support. Traction is still great. They are lighter than the XX, and feel much quicker on foot.

The Lebron NXXT gen was easily one of the best basketball shoes in the many I've worn as a basketball player. Other than that, the shoe was excellent and easily one of the best I've used.

The KD 15 is a great performer. Two major upgrades over the KD 14, one downgrade. The shank plate on the KD 14 was directly under the zoom strobel, and gave me arch pain. The KD 14 was rock solid in this area. The KD 15 has a little heel slippage, but that does go away as you break them in.

The Nike LeBron 19 has plenty of tech and provides the best impact protection you can find right now. However, the traction can be suspect, and they are heavy.

The Nike LeBron 19 is one of the best shoes in the LeBron line in recent years. The cushioning setup is lower to the ground without sacrificing any impact protection, but the biggest improvement is the stability that they feature.
The Nike LeBron 19 doesn't quite fit my playstyle. They do provide impact protection and would be a solid pick for players that enjoy extra cushioning.
Overall, the Nike LeBron 19 is a fun shoe to play in. It provides a crazy amount of bounce, and the cushion feels fantastic. The traction and weight do hold the shoe back, though.

The Nike LeBron 19 offers a lot of tech, especially in the mid and outsole. It's a maximalist shoe that provides plenty of energy return, but it may not be the best shoe for those that rely on speed up and down the court because of the weight.
The Nike LeBron 19 provides an unreal cushioning experience in terms of comfort, but the traction is disappointing. They remain one of the best shoes for those that value impact protection.
Not even the crazy cushion and improved support of the LeBron 19 could make me recommend this shoe. For the price, the traction is just not good.
Overall, I can't recommend the Nike LeBron 19 because of the traction. If you need an awesome cushion setup with a lot of support, this shoe could work for you.

Most fun hooping shoe EVER! With the exception of the materials, this does everything better than the 18. The cushioning feels bouncy and plush. It provides a lot of impact protection because there is so much air.

In the heel, there's a giant Air Max unit. There's also a large Zoom unit in the forefoot. Strictly from a cushion setup, this feels crazy. It doesn't quite fit my playstyle, though.

The materials are soft and supportive. There really isn't anything for me to complain about.

The heel cushion is top tier , shoe in general is responsive with a bit of bounce, traction is maybe like an A- grade (the black outsole picks up less dust than the others surprisingly), slightly wide and long but not to the point where it's affecting the support (heel stayed locked in) and playability, you can go down half a size/double sock if it bothers you so I suggest trying it out first if you can. Only issue I have faced is arch support, but I swapped out my insole and it went away

These are my first ever pair of basketball shoes, so I don’t have a pair to reference or compare them to. Overall I love these. They are very comfortable with good traction. Haven’t used them outside yet so I can’t make a comment on that. Size wise, I stuck true to size, but they do feel a small bit loose around the foot and ankle, but you don’t even notice this when you’re playing. Also to note, they don’t have a tongue, keep this in mind when buying these.
I initially thought the traction would perform well, but they outperformed my expectation. The bite and grip are superb.
The traction pattern uses both herringbone and radial patterns to offer multi-directional coverage.
The grip of the outsole has no slippage whatsoever. The only downside is that it took quite a bit of time for the rubber to break in.
The traction was good on a clean court. But, in dusty conditions, I've played in better shoes.
I had a lot of trouble with the shoe picking up a lot of dust on dirtier courts. On cleaner courts, the traction performed nicely.
The traction performed decently on a clean court, but it was poor on dustier courts.
The traction was solid. The shoe didn't perform well on dusty courts, but they work on most other surfaces.
The Lightstrike midsole and the Boost in the heel felt amazing on the court. It's the perfect guard setup. The shoe is low to the ground while still providing impact protection.
The cushion is great for a first signature shoe. The combination of Lightstrike and Boost makes for a comfortable setup.
In my opinion, the cushioning on the shoe is the ideal setup for an Adidas shoe. The Lightstrike in the forefoot allows for nimble movement, and the Boost in the heel offers shock absorption.
The Trae Young 1 is made of Lightstrike in the forefoot and Boost in the heel. The impact protection feels nice in the back, and the forefoot feels low to the ground; very responsive.

The cushioning setup is my favourite part of the shoe. There is a full-length Lightstrike with Boost in the heel. It feels low to the ground, and the step-in comfort has a decent amount of soft compression.

There is a full-length Lightstrike midsole with Boost in the heel. It is the Lightstrike that we all want to experience. The combination works well together and provides an ample amount of impact protection and responsiveness.
The shoe offers a very good court feel, and the cushion setup works for it.
The full textile upper isn't the most premium, but it performs well. It also feels comfortable and is durable.
The materials provide solid performance. It felt comfortable, and my foot felt locked in.
The upper is wide and minimalist. It performs well, but the comfort takes some time to break in.
The upper is sturdy. It doesn't stretch much, and it has a good structure.
There is a textile mesh-like material that starts stiff but becomes softer the more you play in them.
Mesh is what primarily makes up the upper of the shoe. It has a good structure, and the materials don't feel cheap.
The materials play well, but they aren't the most effective in the forefoot area.
None of the support features blow you away, but the shoe includes all the support standards.
The support could have been much better if the shoe had more lace hole options.
Because of the materials and lack of lacing, the shoe doesn't feel secure on the mid part of your foot. However, the foot is actually quite secure.
The support is solid due to the structure of the upper. However, if the shoe had a better lacing system, the lockdown would be better.
There are no issues with lateral containment and support.
I had no issues with the support in this shoe. There's everything you want and nothing that you don't.
Stability is not an issue in the Trae Young 1. The upper provides support right up to the midfoot, and I was not impressed with the forefoot.
The laces don't do much for the shoe, but the one-piece upper felt good on foot.
The fit isn't snug, so you do have wiggle room.
The fit is not for everybody. The forefoot is boxy, and this can sometimes make movements feel awkward. This shoe is likely best for medium and wide-footers.
Make sure to get the right size because the shoe is fit is only adjustable from the midfoot area up.
The fit was good for me. I had no issues. The only downside is that it isn't customizable with the lack of holes in the lacing system.
There is some extra space in the toe box area, but the shoe doesn't stretch much. So, the shoe fits decently.
The laces don't do anything for fit and support. Overall, the fit was weird on the shoe.
The rubber is soft, so I think the outdoor play will wear away at it quickly.
The rubber held up well during my tests.
The outsole is thick rubber. It looks like it will perform decent outdoors.
The grooves are deep, and there is a lot of rubber. They should be alright when using them outdoors.
The shoe accommodates wide-footers well.
I'd say the shoe has a regular width.
The shoe can be tough to get on for people with wider feet.
Going true to size worked well for me.
Narrow and medium foot shapes should go down half a size. Wide-footers go true to size.
I had to go down half a size because the lacing system is short, making it hard to customize the fit.
I went true to size, and there is only a bit of space in the toe area lengthwise.
I would go true to size.

For the price, the Under Armour Flow FUTR X is a solid shoe. If you don't need a lot of impact protection, this shoe will be perfect for you. It has amazing traction, the fit is solid, and it's plenty supportive.
The Under Armour Flow FUTR X is great for indoor courts and provides an above-average energy return while remaining lightweight and stable.
The traction is top tier, the cushion is responsive, and the support was good. Despite the materials, the Under Armour Flow FUTR X is a definite cop.

Recommended for lighter guards quick wing players. As usual, great traction from UA, Flow does its job again. The cushion in these was surprisingly soft, completely opposite to what i expected and saw in other basketball Flow sneakers. Lockdown and support was just incredible. The midfoot band was a stroke of pure genius.Comfort wise these were great, but not the most breathable. Padded uppers don’t let the most air through. performance, coupled with price make the futr X a great option indoors.
These are great! Should work for most players, maybe more geared towards guards.
Featuring the exact same pattern as the Curry 8, the traction on the Flow FUTR X is great. It's beastly whether the court is clean or dusty.
The better maintained the court surface, the better the traction performs. It's one of the best tractions on clean courts.
The traction is absolutely nuts. It's just like the Curry 8. Amazing.
The full-length Flow cushion is thinner than the Curry 8, so it is more firm. Impact protection isn't great, but the court feel and responsiveness are solid.
The Flow foam feels significant underfoot. The shoe doesn't bottom out that fast and provides solid energy return.
It is a responsive cushion setup, so don't expect much bounce or impact protection.
Materials feel a tad cheap, but they are good in terms of performance.
Under Armour did everything they could to make the shoe as light as possible. That means that it isn't very durable.
The materials feel nice and comfortable. It's thin and minimal.
I had zero issues with the support in the shoe. The strap does actually add support to the midfoot area of the shoe.
The midfoot strap actually provides solid support because it hooks into the shoelaces.
I really liked how Under Armour implemented the midfoot strap. It worked well to tighten and improve lateral containment.
The materials and addition of a strap make the fit of the FUTR X good.
The Under Armour Flow FUTR X is one of the most comfortable fitting shoes I've put on this year.
The fit for me wasn't the best. It gets quite roomy because of the stretch in the material.
It's fairly durable, considering there's no rubber on the outsole.
The durability held up much better than I expected it to be on the Curry 8 and this uses the exact same outsole.
The shoe is wider in the forefoot when you go true to size.
It's good for wide-footers as the materials could stretch to accommodate.
I went true to size and felt ok length-wise.

The Adidas Exhibit A is a refreshing entry into the Adidas basketball lineup. It's lightweight with great traction and materials. The cushion is comfortable and playable but could be better. Overall, the shoe is a reliable performer.
The Adidas Exhibit A is a solid performer for the price. It has a great cushion if you want to feel quick and shifty. The traction is reliable, and the support has everything need in a hoop shoe.
The Adidas Exhibit A is good but is just below the top-tier. The traction gets the job done, the cushion is responsive, and the materials perform well for the quality.
The Adidas Exhibit A is a shoe that offers an excellent cushioning setup, but the mediocre traction is a letdown.
If you are a wide footer you can still go down half a size. The shoe bed is very wide. It’s like this shoe was made for our type of feet.
When the courts are clean, the traction is reliable. There's minimal dust pickup, so an occasional wipe is needed.
A diamond traction pattern has a solid bite on both clean and dusty courts. It's a good kind of consistent.
On clean courts, the diamond pattern performs well. On dusty courts, the traction picks up quite a bit of dust. The performance also improves after a break-in period.
The traction of this shoe is mediocre. It works on clean courts, but anything other than that, it becomes iffy.
The cushion provides lightweight stability in the forefoot and a slight amount of impact protection in the heel.
The Adidas Exhibit A has a full-length Lightstrike midsole that feels firm and responsive. There is some impact protection, but it isn't very prominent.
The full-length Lightstrike feels similar to the Harden Vol. 4 but with much better step-in comfort. It's low to the ground and has a decent amount of compression.
The cushion is a full-length Lightstrike. The court feel of this shoe is magnificent. It doesn't have the best impact protection, but I still loved it.
I'm happy with the materials. Especially the choice to use a more comfortable half-bootie upper. They play well on the court.
For the price, I have no complaints. Adidas did a good job of implementing the materials across the upper.
It's mainly a thin mesh upper. The quality isn't the best, but it works for the price.
The materials feel comfortable enough, but it doesn't offer much support-wise.
As always, Adidas has a solid base of the shoe to help with stability. This time around, I also really liked the heel support. It is minimal yet effective.
The heel support is nicely sculpted. Your heel is locked down, and the wide base covers you laterally.
There are well-placed fuse overlays on the shoe that help to contain your foot.
The heel counter feels rigid, but the laces don't really provide much in terms of support.
Fit can be inconsistent. Once you get the right size for you, the shoe plays nicely.
I experienced some tightness in the midfoot area, but it went away as I broke the shoes in.
There is some space in the toe box, but other than that, I like the fit.
Adidas shoes have fit me weirdly for a while now. I needed to wear cushioned socks and get a smaller size to get a good fit.
I didn't play outdoors with these, but the rubber doesn't feel the most durable.
Even with slightly wide feet, I was ok going down half a size. If you have wider feet, you may still want to go true to size.
It's a regular fitting shoe in terms of width.
I would recommend going down a half size.
I went true to my Adidas size and had no issues.

For $100, this is a fantastic option. It is one of the best D Rose shoes to come out in recent years. It plays quickly and offers plenty of court feel though the impact protection could be better. But for the price, it's hard to beat the Adidas D Rose Son of Chi.
Overall, the Adidas D Rose Son of Chi has good traction and feels responsive. The support is good as well. It just isn't the most minimal feeling shoe in terms of materials.
The D Rose Son of Chi has nice traction, but the cushion isn't anything special. The support plays well enough, but you can tell the materials aren't the best.
Very nice shoe for athletic players, with nice support and fit, also bounce cushion is great, but the materials is not so good, but in outdoor doing normally
I liked how durable and comfortable they are amazing ❤️
Great shoe overall, the bounce it's great in this shoe.
The traction used on this shoe performs nicely. You're going to experience an amazing bite.
The traction performs excellently. I would say the bite is top-tier, especially on clean courts. The only drawback is the dust pickup, but this didn't affect performance after wiping.
The best feature of the shoe is traction. Its herringbone grips the floor so well.
The Son of Chi uses full-length exposed Bounce cushioning. It provides good bounciness and impact protection while still remaining low to the ground.
The full-length Bounce felt a little thin. The compression isn't very noticeable, so impact protection is adequate. However, it is responsive and low to the ground.
The shoe uses Bounce cushioning to provide solid responsiveness. It doesn't have the best impact protection, though.
It doesn't use the most premium-feeling materials, but it gets the job done just fine.
The quality of the materials is not good. It took a while to break them into the point where they felt comfortable.
The materials have a cheaper feel to them. It still performs, but it could've been better.
The lateral stability of the shoe is sturdy. Overall, the support performs well.

The upper is supportive, so my foot felt contained. I had no issues with lateral stability. The Son of Chi also felt restrictive and sturdy in the ankle mobility department. Keep that in mind if that's something you look for in a shoe.
The support of the shoe is good but not great.
The toe box is a bit snug, but the shoe fits decently.
I felt pinching in the midfoot area, but that went away after breaking them in. The materials also don't stretch much, making them feel snug.
The fit on the shoe feels snug. There isn't much extra space provided.
I feel like durability on an outdoor court would be good.
Slightly snug.
I would say go true to size still.

Donovan Mitchell's latest shoe is a step up from last year's model, but the Adidas DON Issue #3 doesn't live up to the original. It has solid traction and adequate cushioning that will suit guard play.
Overall, the D.O.N Issue #3 is a steady basketball shoe. It has dependable traction with a wide base. The cushion and support were also dependable for me.

The Adidas D.O.N Issue #3 has great traction and comfortable materials. It felt comfortable on foot, but the cushion doesn't hold up after playing more than three games at a time. The heel slippage also takes away from the shoe a bit. Overall, it is a responsive shoe that feels light on your feet.

As long as you consistently wipe, you're getting a good-performing shoe. The shoe feels light, the traction performs well enough, and the materials feel nice. The only issue to consider is that there is the potential for heel slippage.
The D.O.N Issue #3 is a lightweight shoe that provided a decent amount of court feel with the Lightstrike midsole. However, the traction, fit, and heel lockdown left a lot to be desired.

An outdoor review: This has good traction for outdoors, but it is decently durable? ive hooped about 30 hours in this, it shoes signs of the traction fading but it still performs well. You should cop these only if theyre discounted. Fun shoes to hoop in but man the cushioning is pretty mid. Not mid i mean, kinda eh. My feet start aching a bit after playing in this, maybe because I jump a lot or take very hard steps. Lock down is decent enough. Oh n dont hoop for long in these, ur feet will melt.

While I did have fun in this shoe I felt like the shoe could improve. Overall the Traction was good and it supported your foot well. But after long time playing in these my feet always got sore and were full of blisters.  The durability i also felt like could do better because after not even a year playing in them they started to break, The cushioning was also not anything write home about.

I think everyone doesn’t talk about it but i think its so good. It can play outdoors with good traction. But it can’t protect to much. The Upper did received some signs of wear. The Materials is one of the best. The cushion is maybe fair but it took me 3 hours to break in. Support was fine. Overall its one of the best Traction and comfortable material of adidas

The D.O.N. Issue 3 was actually pretty good in my opinion. The Traction stopped on a dime but you have to wipe every now and then. The cushion is plush but very responsive.  The materials are comfortable and they feel snug on foot. The support and fit are solid, I wasn't sliding out for the most part. But overall, I recommend the D.O.N. Issue 3 to all types of hoopers in the world.
Overall, the traction works well. It sticks hard but can be affected by dust.
The traction is a huge upgrade for Mitchell's signature line. The grooves are wider and thicker which helps it grip better.
The traction on these is pretty good on both indoor and outdoor courts.
The spiderweb-like traction pattern is pretty good for the most part. I slipped a bit, but it was minimal.
The traction was not that good. It was inconsistent, and for the most part, it did not bite as hard as other shoes on the market. It performed well indoors, but on dusty courts, I was sliding a lot.
The full-length Lightstrike midsole offers plushness and comfort, but it lacks the bounciness of other cushions. It also feels responsive.
The cushion in the D.O.N Issue #3s sits somewhere between the Harden Vol. 4 and the Dame 7. It has a little bit of bounciness but is very responsive.
The feel of the cushion is similar to the Harden 4 and the Dame 7, but it is thicker. It's responsive and light but isn't the plushest cushion.
The Lightstrike feels exactly like what you would expect. It's similar to Bounce but not as dense. The shoe feels responsive, and it has good heel cushioning.
The full-length Lightstrike is nice because it is lightweight. It provides a good amount of court feel but is lacking in impact protection.
The materials don't feel premium, but they are soft to the touch. I didn't have any problems playing in the shoe.
The materials don't require any break-in time and appear to be decently durable.
The tongue feels really nice, and the overall materials remind me of the Dame 2. They require no break-in time but aren't the most breathable.
The upper is completely textile, but some rubber and fuse hits are placed strategically for durability. They definitely get the job done.
After an initial break-in period, the materials are a definite upgrade from the D.O.N Issue #2. It performs well and feels soft once broken in.
I think that support is one of the best aspects of the shoe. The shoe feels stable and secure.
I experienced no heel slippage. The footbed keeps you very well contained.
The lateral TPU provides good support and keeps you contained laterally. The downside is that I experienced quite a bit of heel slippage.
I had some heel slippage in only my right shoe. Nothing too extreme, but just noticeable enough to make me feel a bit insecure. Everything else about the support felt good.
For lateral containment, I had no issues. The setup with the foam coming up the sides of the shoe performed well. I did have a little heel slippage, but that is mostly subjective to my foot.
The fit is solid in the midfoot, but there is space in the forefoot. I also experienced a lot of heel slippage because of the sock liner.
The fit is not as snug as other recent Adidas models in the midfoot, which is a welcome improvement for me.
I was able to go true to size.
The materials lay nicely over your feet, and the tongue feels nice as well.
The fit is not for me. It fit well length-wise, but the toe box had a lot of extra room. You may like it if you like a roomier fit.
The rubber is hard, and I didn't experience much fraying.
There's isn't much fraying on my pair yet.
The rubber is fairly hard, but the grooves aren't the best.
The shoe does a decent job of accommodating wider feet.
I have slightly wide feet, and the shoe felt good going down half a size. Keep in mind, it may feel tight when first trying them on.
It is a little bit wide.
Go half a size down for regular footers and true to size for wide footers.
I recommend going down half a size.
It fit true to size, but there is too much space in the forefoot for my liking.

The Nike Zoom Freak 3 provides a good amount of tech at an affordable price point. They're an upgrade both performance-wise and aesthetics-wise compared to previous models. The cushion feels great, the materials get the job done, and the traction performs well after breaking it in. These are definitely a shoe going into my rotation.

In my opinion, the Nike Zoom Freak 3 makes major improvements compared to the Zoom Freak 2. The traction is close to being a top-tier performer, and the cushion is nice and bouncy. I'd definitely recommend it.

The Nike Zoom Freak 3 is one of my favourite shoes to hoop in right now. The cushion is bouncy, the traction is one of my favourites on the market right now, and in my opinion, they look pretty darn good.
The Zoom Freak 3 is good, not great. The traction is inconsistent. There is good breathability for your foot and good support.

The Zoom Freak 3 is a solid shoe at its current price point. The traction was inconsistent, but the materials, fit, and support make up for it. Overall, Nike did a good job of upgrading the shoe from the Zoom Freak 2.
The Nike Zoom Freak 3 is a lightweight and minimal shoe. The traction was inconsistent for me, and I was disappointed in the cushion. However, I did like the materials, and the shoe has a great fit.
Overall, the Nike Zoom Freak 3 is a decent shoe if you have a similar playstyle to the Freak himself. The traction performs well, but the support of the shoe was a letdown.

2 hours is how much it took the shoes to break. I have been using adidas products for quite a long time and I've played with my pair of issue 2 for almost two years. I bought the freaks 3 from the official nike store and right after receiving them, I decided to try them on an outside court close to where I live. I played 1v1 against my friend and I fell in a way my upper foot put lots of friction on the thin material there. I can see my foot now. Issue 2 served me for 2 years freaks for 2 hours.

Cushioning was average for me; the twin Zoom pods didn't have enough room to compress, and when you see the midsole teardown by foot doctor Zach, you can see where I am coming from. This shoe does feel unstable. I didn't really feel that springboard effect from a shoe I expected to do just that. Traction was also inconsistent. Support was great, the strap worked well and it has

Despite the lackluster reviews thus far, this shoe is a standout performer for me as a larger wing/forward. The traction does its job after breaking in, the cushion is awesome for me with a powerful bounce that makes me feel explosive. Though heel cushioning is minimal, it doesn't matter too much as the forefoot feels so good and propels you forward. I went from a 14 to 15 with this shoe and it fits well. It is nice and wide, materials are awesome and support is top tier.  This shoe is a win.

The Zoom Freak 3 is a good shoe, but felt like a step back for the Zoom Freak line. With a decoupled outsole these are extremely flexible. There is a shank plate, but that doesn’t prevent some of the instability you can feel in this shoe. That is largely caused by the 2 side by side zoom pods in the forefoot. They are directly against the very thin outsole, and while they provide a lot of bounce and propulsion, they can also leave you feeling a little wobbly on hard cuts.

This shoe is one of the most comfortable shoes I’ve ever tried on. The traction is amazing but the durability of it is weak as it might break or tear off the more you use it. The materials is great but can do better. This is a very lightweight shoe so I would recommend guards to wear this shoe. But overall this shoe is great, not one of the best shoes out there compared to other signature shoes but is a great shoe to hoop in.
After a break-in period, the Zoom Freak 3 gripped the floor fairly well. They pick up a lot of dust as well.

The traction has a good bite and stopping power that works in all directions. It's one of the gripper tractions to come out this year, but I'd put them just below the top tier because of occasional dust pickup.
The shoe gripped nicely on all types of court surfaces. I think this is mostly due to the traction pattern.
The traction can grip courts quite nicely, but it can be inconsistent. I don't have any complaints beyond that.
The traction was inconsistent regardless of court conditions. I experienced a bit of sliding but never actually slipped out.
I'm disappointed in the traction. The bite is inconsistent despite dust not being an issue.
For the most part, the traction does its job on clean courts. On a dusty court, they do start to pick up debris. The traction performs well but isn't the best that Nike has to offer.
The midsole is lightweight and bouncy. The two Zoom units in the forefoot also feel responsive, bouncy, and springy.
The full-length injected Phylon midsole is nice and soft, while the two giant Zoom pods in the forefoot feel bouncy.
In my opinion, the cushion in the Zoom Freak 3 is an upgrade. The shoe features a pair of forefoot Zoom pods that feel bouncy after breaking them in.
The cushioning on these is noticeably more comfortable than last year's model. This comfort comes from two Zoom Air pods included in the forefoot.
The Phylon used in the shoe is stiff and provides little impact protection. At the forefoot of the shoe, the Zoom pods are caged and aren't as springy as I would've liked.

There isn't much compression with the full-length Phylon. The bottom-loaded Zoom units in the forefoot also didn't offer much in terms of bounce. However, the cushion does provide decent responsiveness.

The Freak 3 features a Phylon midsole with two large Zoom pods in the forefoot. The heel is plush and feels good on feet. The forefoot Zoom doesn't quite offer the responsive feeling you've come to expect from Zoom Air.
There is a combination of mesh and synthetics. It's not premium, but it gets the job done.
The Zoom Freak 3 makes use of some pretty basic materials. It feels thin, but it gets the job done.
The Freak 3 uses a mix of fuse and mesh that feels similar to the KD 14. They're well ventilated, and they're pretty good in terms of durability.
The quality of the materials used could be better considering Giannis's use of the euro step.
The materials are thin but sturdy. They're more than capable of getting the job done.
The quality of the materials feels nice when held in hand. On foot, they're comfortable and get the job done.
The strap doesn't provide much for performance, but the laces perform well. The outrigger and padded heel also work well to provide support and lockdown.

The support is adequate. It does have a wide base and lateral outrigger that perform well. However, the strap is useless, and the torsional support can be a problem for those with plantar-related issues.
I experienced no heel slippage, and the lateral containment of the shoe really gets the job done. The wide base also helps to keep you on the footbed.
The materials and base of the shoe help provide solid support.
I didn't have any issues with the support. There is plenty of heel padding to secure your heel. The materials also do a great job of containing your foot laterally.
I had no issues with lateral containment or lateral stability as the shoe has a wide base.

The strap doesn't really offer much for lockdown. Most of that actually comes from the lacing and materials. There isn't much lateral support coming from this shoe though. It feels similar to the PG 4 where my foot rolls off the footbed sometimes.
They fit snug right out of the box, but they do stretch after a break-in period.
The upper is soft and forgiving to help it conform to your foot. The lacing system and padded rear of the shoe also help to keep you locked in.
There is more room in the toe box of the Freak 3, making for a better fit.
The narrow forefoot area makes the shoe fit snug. This snug fit can cause issues for players with wider feet.
The fit starts out snug but breaks in to fit nicely.
They fit my foot perfectly.
The rubber compound used is soft and likely won't hold up well outdoors.
The rubber appears to be durable.
The rubber is fairly soft and probably isn't the best when playing outdoors.
I don't recommend using these outdoors.
The shoe is more wide footer friendly than the previous Freak models as the mid and forefoot have more space.
These definitely fit narrow.
It is a bit narrow on the lateral side of the forefoot. Wide footers go up a half size, but everyone else should go true to size.
Width-wise, these are pretty normal. The forefoot area does expand over time as well.
Not wide foot friendly at all. They are very narrow.
I did go true to size, and it fits me perfectly well.
Regular footers can go true to size, but wide footers still might want to go half a size up.
I recommend going half size up or avoiding the shoe if you have wider feet.
True to size fit for me as I only have a slightly wide foot.
I went true to size and had no problems at all.
They fit true to size.
The Nike Air Zoom G.T. Run isn't too impressive straight out of the box, but after breaking them in, they slowly become better. There is plenty of cushioning, and the traction becomes solid.

Overall, the Nike Air Zoom G.T. Run is a really nice shoe. The only gripes I have are the less-than-premium materials and the traction when on dirtier courts. Other than that, you get tonnes of cushion, the support and lockdown are good, and the fit is solid.

If you're looking for a crazy cushioning setup, the Nike Air Zoom G.T. Run is the shoe for you. It's a solid shoe for anyone who doesn't mind giving up some court feel and responsiveness to get more impact protection and bounciness.
The Nike Air Zoom GT Run is a solid shoe for those that are looking for an explosive setup and rely on a lot of jumping in their game.
The Nike Zoom GT Run offers solid traction while it lasts and plenty of impact protection. It could be more premium, but it performs well enough.
The G.T. Run is the worst performer of the 3 Greater Than models. The shoe has good cushioning and traction. However, the support isn't easy to trust with how thin the materials are.
The shoe is good but i slips sometimes on dusty courts.
The rubber compound is hard at the beginning. However, the traction does become pliable and more impressive to play in as you wear them more often.
The traction is pretty good on cleaner courts with a strong bite, but it is somewhat slippery on dustier courts even though it doesn't pick up much dust.
On a clean court, there is a solid bite. But on a dirtier court, it picks up dust pretty quickly. A quick wipe made things tolerable.
The pattern provides outstanding suction on hardwood courts.
I found the traction to be consistent on front-to-back movements. However, when going side-to-side, I did slide a bit.
The traction pattern covers you in all directions.

The full-length React outsole is denser than the React used in Nike's running shoes making the impact protection excellent. The two layers of Zoom units in the forefoot also make the shoe very bouncy.
There is a lot of cushion with a react midsole, a react insole, a forefoot Zoom unit, and a forefoot Zoom Strobel unit. You get a lot of impact protection, and it is very bouncy.
The cushion setup is insane. There is a lot of compression in the forefoot due to the Zoom Strobel. The tradeoff is that there isn't as much court feel, but if you love cushion, this is amazing.
The double-stacked Zoom Air units provide max cushion for movements like pivoting and jumping.
There's a forefoot Zoom Strobel, a Zoom bag beneath that, and a React midsole in the shoe. I found this setup comfortable, but it is high off the ground.
The shoe features a double-stacked forefoot Zoom setup that offers a good amount of cushion.
The upper is rigid and stiff, but after a break-in period, they do soften up, and the performance improves over time.
The dual-layered upper is the least premium aspect of the shoe. It feels cheap and does not look good after playing in them. However, from a performance perspective, they get the job done.
The quality of the materials is not great compared to the price of the shoe. It does conform to your foot nicely, but it doesn't feel premium.
There's a lack of materials on the tongue that causes some irritation. Along with being light and airy, these are actually surprisingly durable.
The mesh upper is minimal. I had no issues performance-wise, but they could've been more premium.
The mesh helps keep the shoe light and breathable.
The heel padding helps to prevent heel slippage, while the raised midsole and rigid upper keep you contained in the shoe.
I had no issues with support or lockdown. Your feet aren't going anywhere with the midsole that rises and the wide base of the shoe.

I had some heel slippage, which was annoying, but the insole does a good job of keeping your foot on the footbed. Laterally, I had no issues due to the foam that rises along the midfoot to cage you in.
The upper is a lot more secure than they look. My only concern is that the cushion setup can cause a bit of pronation.
The midsole and the plastic lateral plate hold your foot securely. The forefoot is also wide and stable.
The midsole spikes up in the midfoot area to offer lateral support, which I appreciated. The heel portion of the shoe also feels sturdy and secure.
It's a fairly narrow-fitting sneaker despite being a bit long in the forefoot area. Regardless, I had no issue with the fit.
The upper fits nicely on top of your foot, and I had no issues with the fit when I went true to size.
The fit is snug in the toe box, which is something I like.
Initially, it's hard to get your foot in. However, they do break in nicely because of the mesh materials.
I felt some pinching the first few times I played in the shoe, but it went away eventually.
The speckled pattern in the shoe caused some irritation for me where the shoe creased. It didn't affect the performance, but it is worth noting.
They should be alright for occasional outdoor use.
I don't think it's going to be durable enough for outdoor use.
The treads aren't too thick. They won't last long outdoors.
The tread is thin and not deep enough to hold up outdoors.
If you have wide feet, I would recommend going up half a size.
The fit is slightly narrow in the forefoot.
If you have a wide and flat foot, this isn't the shoe for you.
It runs narrow, even for me.
I went true to size and felt perfectly fine.
I went true to size, and it was perfect for me.
They are true to size, and the shoe accommodates most feet well.
This shoe does run true to size.
I went true to size. The shoe fits a bit bigger than the Nike GT Cut.

The Nike Giannis Immortality is one of the best signature athlete budget models available. It performs just as well as some signature models despite lacking the same tech that they feature. Definitely a great bang for your buck type of shoe.

When you're playing in the Giannis Immortality, you feel very light and really quick. The traction is amazing, and the cushion is responsive. Support could've been a bit better, but it wasn't a deal-breaker. I really like this shoe.

The Nike Giannis Immortality is a pretty decent budget model. However, there are other shoes at the price point that do outperform the shoe. The cushion and materials feel nice, but I did have issues with support.
The Giannis Immortality is a solid performer in the subline of Giannis's Zoom Freak line with Nike. These also provide lateral containment and consistent traction while also feeling light.

The shoe is a super light and responsive, geared toward smaller players. The traction has almost no slips on clean courts, but absorbs dust like a vacuum on moderately dusty courts. The support fits really well with amazing heel support, but be careful with the thin material, as I almost ripped through one of the shoes zion style after only 2 months of using it. A tear by the big toe is common, and is where I have it on my right shoe. Other than that, it's really only worth it when its on sale.

Kinda mid tbh, I expected more about the traction but they will probably get better once a fully break them in so I will give it a 9, cushion is alright, good responsiveness tho, the worst feature in the shoe is definitely the support, the materials are really lightweight and minimal but cheap, I am concern about the durability of the upper but the durability of the traction should be pretty good, overall a solid shoe for guards who are on a budget and want a lightweight, responsive shoe.

Best feature is the support - foot feels very locked in. However the cushion is a bit lacking which is a little disappointing given the bulkiness of the heal. Court feel of the forefoot feels great, but my personal preference would be to have a less bulky heal. And if the heal is bulky, as in this case, would think it would have a little more cushion. Materials are good, especially the soft materials. Also think these are a pretty low profile shoe (again think the heal is a little much)

this is the first budget shoe from the Giannis line. the traction held up pretty well, but it's not the best. The support has never been a problem in the Giannis line. I did experience one problem in the shoe, which was that the materials in the upper tore after just a couple months of playing in them. The cushion was lackluster because it was a budget shoe, but what could you expect? It is a solid performer, but there are so many better options available right now.

The shoes are kinda comfortable. They are kinda narrow (Especially in the toebox) The ankle support isn't good and I got a pretty bad ankle sprain playing in them. They did pick up some dust. If you have a wide feet go up half a size. I went true to size and experience some lateral pain. The shoe causes me blisters. The materials are very breathable. If you have plantar fascitis I don't recommend this shoe. This review was posted after 5 months of constant use.
No surprise that herringbone traction gets the job done. The Immortality performed very well. Wiping wasn't needed because of the deep grooves in the traction pattern.
The traction is top-tier. It's one of the best patterns that you can get right now. The bite is insane on clean courts, and it wasn't picking up much dust on dirtier courts.
The traction is just ok despite being herringbone. It performs well on clean courts, but on your average court, you'll find yourself sliding quite a bit.
Traction is one of the standout points of the shoe. It provides a consistent playing experience.
Being a budget option, the cushion used is just Phylon. Regardless, it performs decent enough, especially after a short break-in period.
There's nothing special in terms of the tech used for the cushion. It's low to the ground and still provides impact protection.
The Giannis Immortality features a full-length Phylon cushion that's just okay. It's more on the firmer side, but you'll still get some impact protection.
The Phylon midsole performs better than expected, but it's not the main feature.
Even though the materials are comfortable, they are also thin. Lots of mesh and synthetics were used on this model.
The textile mesh is thin, but I love the way it feels for the price. However, the synthetic materials used towards the back half of the shoe aren't the best.
The mesh material feels nice to the touch, but the performance is a bit lacklustre.
It's clear that these aren't the most high-quality materials. It is breathable and lightweight, though.
The curved edge at the back of the shoe helps with rolling into your stride, but it also makes the shoe feel a bit wobbly. At the front of the shoe, the outrigger is amazing.
The torsional support isn't the best. The lateral containment wasn't bad, and the shoe did its job stability-wise.
There's not enough heel padding in the back of the shoe, which caused heel slippage. I also felt my foot sliding off the footbed, but the shoe does have a wide base and a decent outrigger.
There is solid lateral containment since side-to-side coverage is a focal point for Giannis's playstyle.
They fit snug to start off but loosen up after a few hours played.
The fit for me was perfect. It started out snug but loosened up over time.
It fits slightly long, and the materials lie nicely on the top of the foot.
It has a snug fit in the beginning before breaking them in.
The rubber is fairly hard, the grooves are deep, and the price is low. It's a pretty good outdoor option.
It should be fine for most, but if you have wider feet, you may want to go up half a size.
I wouldn't call these narrow, but they can fit snug.
They do run true to size for the most part.
I would recommend staying with your true size with these because the materials stretch out.

Although I was disappointed in the cushion, the Nike Kyrie Low 4 still provides a smooth, lightweight experience. The traction, fit, and support combine to make this shoe a decent performer at a reasonable price.

The Nike Kyrie Low 4 is a pretty low to the ground, responsive setup, but doesn't provide much bounce or compression. It plays very fast and the shoe itself is very lightweight thanks to the thin materials. It's still a shoe I really liked playing in despite being a bit disappointed in the cushion.
The Nike Kyrie Low 4 is an overall good performer. One thing to note is that the shoe isn't the best for impact protection, but it does offer a lot of responsiveness, and the support is great.

Kyrie Low 4’s are a good pickup for indoor use. The traction is great and won’t disappoint. I always felt locked down and well supported in the shoe. However, the shoe’s lower price limits the cushion and durability. Once the shoe bottoms out, I had sore feet from the thin cushion. I was suprised when I found a small tear in the shoe a few months after their first use.   Lastly, I find the weight of the shoe a bit extra. They’re a great cheap shoe, but  sacrifice some comfort and durability.

This shoe had me feeling fairly bouncy and it had great stability and containment, although the cushion isnt great. There was some heel slippage but it was nothing too bad and was not a deal breaker, the traction is great on a clean indoor court but the durability was not great. I played on an outdoor court for a week and i ran through most of the outsole.

The traction is good but the longer I wore them it got worse and I played indoors. Cushion is not that good. It is responsive and low to ground however impact protection is not good. My foot felt really supported in them and I did not experience heel slippage. I would say that for the price tag it is a very good performer.

Its is a pretty solid shoe with OK traction. But you can see the little hump near the heel this part is really hard and I almost always leave practice/games with blisters on my heel. Other than that your getting what you payed for
I absolutely love this shoe. Super responsive cushioning. The cushlon was pretty soft and offered good impact protection, but didn't feel slow at all. Overall great performer.
The Kyrie Low 4 has the same outsole that's used on the Kyrie 7. That means you can expect the same consistency and reliability as well.
The traction is amazing, top-tier traction. The pattern and rubber compound are exactly the same as on the Kyrie 7. It bites really hard on indoor courts.
The traction pattern on the Kyrie Low 4 is exactly the same as the Kyrie 7. They perform the same, so you may need some wiping every now and then.
The Cushlon used is dense, and there's only a small amount of Zoom coverage. This means there isn't much impact protection but, there is plenty of court feel.

The Cushlon used in the Kyrie Low 4 feels different than the Cushlon used in the KD 14 and the Kobe 5 Protro. There isn't as much heel compression and is stiffer than both of the other mentioned pairs.
There's a full-length Cushlon midsole and a Zoom unit in the forefoot, which is a bit of a letdown. It's a firm setup, and I could barely feel the Zoom unit.
Materials on the Kyrie Low 4 are both flexible and breathable. They feel like an extension of your foot.
I really like the materials, but the quality isn't the best. It's a thin textile material that feels very soft and minimal.
The textile upper is nice to the touch and gets the job done in terms of performance.
The support in this shoe is fantastic. With a proper fit, the materials and the low cut help give you a secure ride in all directions.

I experienced a little bit of heel slippage since there isn't much padding in the heel area. It wasn't a deal-breaker, but I just didn't quite feel locked down. Lateral containment had zero issues though.
I had no problems with support. There was no movement of my foot on the footbed. I never felt unstable, especially with the wide base.
The strength of the upper leaves little room for stretch, so going true to size will help provide extra room for toe splay in the forefoot.
It fits exactly like the Kyrie 7. I went true to size and it fits me very well.
The shoe fits snugly and leans toward the narrow side. It caused a bit of discomfort in the forefoot, but other than that, the shoe does fit nicely around my foot.
Do not play with these outdoors at all. I ran through the rubber outsole in about 2 days.
It does run slightly narrow in the toe box.
I'm a slightly wide footer, and this shoe fits narrow when I went true to size.
I recommend going up half a size unless you're looking for a snug fit. I personally like a snug fit, but I think it might cause some discomfort for people who don't.
Going true to size is perfectly fine if you have normal feet.

The Curry 3Z5 is an amazing shoe for only $80. The traction is phenomenal. The Micro G feels soft and responsive like the Micro G of old, and the fit was perfect. The only downside is that the heel area was a bit uncomfortable when I was breaking it in. Overall, the shoe felt amazing.
At a retail price of $80, the Curry 3Z5 is a solid shoe. I have no complaints outside of the dust pickup on dirtier courts, but that's just nitpicking since it still performed nicely.

Traction is the best part of this shoe. Like the other Curry models it has above average traction. Although you have to wipe pretty often The traction is probably the best feature of the shoe. It is pretty light and quick for the price. It started to wear down at probably about 20 games of basketball. The support and stability is not very good but for its price it packs a punch.
The traction is crazy good, and the micro g in the midsole is bouncy and has insane impact protection, and the shoe fits like a glove.
Traction’s terrible. The cushion and support is great. If we could get some traction, this would be a very solid shoe.
They are a great budget shoe and perform perfect in my opinion these are my favorite basketbal shoes ever
Best basketball shoe for its price! Get it the price is amazing
The traction has a solid bite on clean courts. On dustier settings, it does pick up some dust, but it's not that frequent.
Overall, the traction is pretty good. You'll have no issues on cleaner courts, but dust does get stuck on dirtier courts. Make sure to wipe to maintain consistency.
The full-length Micro G feels like old-school Micro G. You feel very low to the ground with good impact protection.
There is a full-length Micro G midsole. It's thick in the heel and tapers off in the forefoot. There's a good amount of impact protection in the heel, but the forefoot provides plenty of court feel.
The materials are pretty thin, but I love how it feels on foot. It's very comfortable, and the materials move well with your foot.
It's primarily made of mesh. For the price, it does feel nice.
The heel area around the back of my foot dug into my heel a bit. It wouldn't hurt because of the padding, but it hindered my ankle movement a little bit. The lateral containment caused me no issues.
I never had any feeling of instability when playing in this shoe.
The length was perfect, and the toe box fits nice and snug. If it's a bit tight at first, give it some time, and it will stretch when it breaks in.
I had no issues with the fit at all. There was no tightness in the midfoot, and even the minimal bubbling in the toebox was unnoticeable.
There are areas of thinner rubber on the outsole. It probably isn't going to be the best for outdoor play.
The outsole rubber feels too soft to hold up well outdoors, but the price point makes it more palatable.
If you have a wider foot, you may want to consider going half a size up.

The Nike Air Zoom GT Cut is my favourite Nike basketball shoe this year. It offers a Kobe-like setup that's lightweight with fantastic cushioning. The traction holds up, and the shoe is comfortable right out of the box.
The Nike Air Zoom G.T. Cut is a perfect indoor basketball shoe. They are the definite best shoe to release in 2021 for shifty and quick players who emphasize lockdown, cushion, and traction.

If you love the Kobe 8, you'll love these. The shoe does an excellent job of providing a low-profile, lightweight setup that still provides a decent amount of cushioning. However, I would recommend playing indoors to get the most out of the traction.
The Nike Air Zoom GT Cut is as close to a Kobe as it gets. The cushion is one of the best on the market, and the traction performed well. These kill it on the court.

For people that like low-profile sneakers, this is a must-have in your collection. The cushion is an amazing combination of responsiveness and bounce, and the traction performs very well. The only thing to watch out for is that the shoe does fit snug.

This a top-tier performer. The cushion is phenomenal and the traction performs really nice as long as you wipe to keep dust from building up. It can get a little tight in the forefoot area, but not enough to take away from the performance.

This review is for outdoor performance. The Nike Air Zoom GT Cut is easily worth the money. I don't use the word often, but these are fantastic. The traction holds up well, and the cushion is one of the best available.

The cushion in this shoe is one of the best setups for fast and shifty players. It's a great performer but is a bit expensive coming in at $170 retail. However, I feel the performance makes the shoe worth it.

Before giving Cuts to my HS son for his season, I had to try them to determine if they lived up to the hype (and aftermarket price tag). Apparently, I just had to play regularly almost 40 years to find the ultimate basketball shoe. Each player is unique but to me, this is the 1st time you can legitimately satisfy as many of those potential needs as possible (at any position

This is the best shoe I have ever hooped in. My only complaint is that Nike never really gave people a chance to buy them for a fair price. Both of mine came from marked up resellers. The only real knock on these is that the tongue traps a lot of heat. The traction is great, but isn’t the most long lasting design. Some people complained about the weight in the heel, but I actually liked that.

One of the best shoes ever made. Traction is top tier just have to wipe, support and lockdown are amazing. Cushioning is phenomenal with the full air zoom though the drop in does bottom out. Shoe has some weight to it but not bad at all. Overall these and Lebron 20 are probably the best I’ve played in so far.
With both the react and the zoom air tech this shoe is a top tier performer and for me a cheat code.One of the best shoes in the market right now.If u find it under 200 bucks just buy it.
Traction on dusty courts is not very good. Other than that it’s solid.
I had no real issues with the traction pattern. It performed great in all court conditions.
It has an aggressive traction pattern which, when combined with the rubber compound, provides a loud and tacky bite when playing. It works on both clean and dusty courts (with some wiping).
The traction indoors was awesome. There was a little bit of a break-in time, but they became very grippy.
The indoor performance is better than outdoor performance, but they feel sticky and grip well regardless.
One of the better tractions available on the market.
On a dusty court, the traction picked up a bit of dust, but after a wipe, it was good to go. When playing on a clean court, the stopping power was amazing. The bite was also top tier.
Outdoor review: The unique traction pattern grips very well in most conditions.
The traction on here is actually really nice. You won't have problems with clean courts. It does pick up quite a bit of dust, but as long as you're wiping, it'll still be good.
The cushion feels like a Kobe shoe due to the drop-in React midsole. The Zoom Air unit in the heel provides solid impact protection, while the Zoom Strobel allows the forefoot to remain responsive.
The cushioning on the shoe is simply amazing. The React midsole is responsive. The full-length Zoom Strobel and double-stacked heel Zoom feel very bouncy.
The cushion is my favorite part about the shoe. They have a drop-in React midsole and a full-length Zoom Strobel that, once broken in, starts to mold to your foot.
The cushioning is the main highlight of the shoe. The combination of React, Zoom Strobel and heel Zoom Air is fantastic for impact protection while remaining low to the ground.
The cushion is the best by far for a sneaker that is this low to the ground. It feels very bouncy and still provides lots of impact protection.

The cushion is my favorite part about the shoe. There's a drop-in, full-length react midsole and full-length Zoom strobel underneath. The shoe is very low to the ground with little compression, but it still feels bouncy thanks to the Zoom strobel.

Outdoor review: The cushioning is one of my favourite features of this shoe. They use a React insole that provides solid impact protection. There's also a full-length Zoom Strobel underneath combined with a heel Zoom Air unit.
The cushion in this shoe is amazing. It gives you pretty much everything you want. Great responsiveness, impact protection, and bounciness.
Mesh and neoprene combine to offer a comfortable fit right out of the box. They're also breathable and plenty durable.
The materials are great. The shoe is very comfortable with lots of airflow. There was very little break-in and I was surprised with just how durable the upper turned out to be.
The mesh upper is really nice on this design. It's light and breathable.
The upper is made of mesh that offers extra reinforcement in high wear areas. The placement is well thought out by Nike.
The forefoot feels like a canvas material and the midfoot area feels somewhat like flyknit. There's a tiny bit of padding on the tongue, keeping the shoe fairly minimal.
Outdoor review: There aren't any premium touches like leather, but the mesh does not feel cheap at all. It feels nice and is breathable.
The materials on the upper feel very nice, durable, and breathable. They use quality materials that get the job done.
The plastic forefoot cage provides lateral containment. The torsional plate also offers fantastic torsional rigidity.

The React footbed has a pattern that helps keep your foot from sliding on the footbed. The internal heel counter performs well, and I really like the lacing setup. I think the lockdown is perfect, but the support feels just average. I wish they added an outrigger.
The lockdown was fantastic. On certain movements, I could hear a noise from the heel, but it didn't affect the performance.
There's not much give to the upper, and the rail guard, on the lateral side of the shoe, helps keep your feet contained on lateral movements.
It's one of the most supportive sneakers I've ever worn. You feel very contained, especially on lateral cuts. The shoe also has very nice heel cushioning.
As far as support and lockdown go, there are zero issues. The drop-in midsole cups your foot to help the plastic material along the lateral side of the shoe contain your foot.
Outdoor review: There aren't any outstanding aspects for stability, but it's not lacking either. The heel and ankle support keeps your foot locked in.
I didn't have any support issues in this shoe. The heel counter is very supportive and I felt no shifting on the footbed in the forefoot area.
These fit me perfectly length-wise. The tongue and lacing system are also helpful for customizing the fit.
They fit me just the way I like my shoes to fit.
The fit is perfect for me width and length-wise.
The shoe fits pretty snug in the forefoot area.
My toe goes right to the edge of the shoe in terms of length, so it fits a bit snug in the toe box area. Other than that, the shoe fit great.
These fit me perfectly.
The fit was pretty nice, but one thing to note is there is a bit of pressure near your pinky toe area coming from the side of the shoe.
I would recommend these indoors and outdoors because the rubber is hard.
I'd say durability is less than stellar. I wouldn't recommend taking these outdoors.
I have not played with them outdoors, but the rubber compound seems like it would be ok.
For this review, I played outdoors, and the rubber has helped up nicely.
These should accommodate most foot shapes.
Slightly narrow and I could feel the plastic on the lateral side of the shoe squeezing my foot a tiny bit. It wasn't enough to bother me though.
It isn't very narrow, so it should be usable for all foot types.
If you have really wide feet, you may feel pressure coming from a plastic piece on the lateral side of the shoe.
It fits true to size.
I had no issues with going true to size.
If you have a regular shaped foot, you should be good with going true to size. Wide footers may want to consider going up half a size.
I went true to size and it fits me very well. If you don't like a snug fit, lengthwise, I would suggest going up half a size.
I went true to size and had no issues.
I am a slightly wide footer and I felt pretty good.
The shoe very much feels like a budget model. There are certain aspects of the shoe that could have been done much better, but the mid-tier tech is what was put in the shoe instead.
The Jordan Zion 1 is one of my favourite shoes. The cushioning is comfortable, and the lockdown and stability are solid.

Every aspect of this shoe is solid. There is nothing amazing about this shoe, but there's nothing bad about it either. For $120 you get a solid first signature shoe that works for all types of players.

If you want a comfortable shoe that provides a lot of bounce and protection, this is a great shoe to pick up. On the flip side, because the cushion is very bouncy, the shoe does feel a bit slow. Couple that with the traction not being the most consistent, this shoe may not be the best fit for everyone.
The Jordan Zion 1 is a good place to start Zion's signature shoe line. This is a well-balanced performer.
Overall, if you like a firmer cushion setup, I think you'll enjoy the Jordan Zion 1. The shoe is super supportive, and the rubber is solid enough that it could be a decent outdoor pair.
The Zion 1 is a solid first signature shoe and was fun to play in. I just wish that they had used more premium materials.

The Jordan Zion 1 provides a smooth ride that leads you into the extra bottom-loaded Zoom unit in the forefoot for some extra nice pop. However, its shortcomings are a bit too much to overcome. The fit is not versatile enough to accommodate more types of foot shapes and I experienced quite a bit of slipping with the traction and in the heel area of the shoe.

Shoe feels great on foot. Very light and responsive. Traction is pretty bad on a dusty court. I’m constantly wiping. On a clean court, it has a pretty good stop. This is for the translucent outsole, so the solid rubber might work better. The outsole piece protruding out the bottom provides great support, and the materials feel a little cheap but ventilated. Overall I would recommend this shoe to someone who doesn’t play ball seriously because it is solid for the price.

The Zion 1 is a decent all-around option, a good budget option (on discount) for players looking for a cushiony and supportive shoe. Traction is inconsistent especially on dust, but lateral support is great, as is the cushion, especially in the forefoot. Materials are pretty solid, are light and breathable, but the tongue padding is a little disappointing. I would suggest this shoe for bigger guys who (like Zion), need lateral stability and cushioning.

I got the Zions in January of 2022 and I am just starting to grow out of them, I have only been using them on outdoor courts and the occasional indoor courts, but these have been amazing for me, the durability has been amazing, I have just found the first tiny hole in the side of the shoe just before the midsole and it been because the of the glue, the grip is still amazing (the shoes are almost bald), cushioning has been amazing aswell.

This ones is in my rotation right now. Frankly speaking it's really god option for 60$ but not for 110$. This pair collects dust better than vacuum cleaner, but on the clean surface their traction is gourgeous... If you want to buy this ones get ready for sweaty feets because this pair have no vent. Cushion isn't as good how it seems to be. Supportiveness is one of the best i tried.

I really like playing in these shoes, the traction and extra ankle support really gives me confidence that I won't suffer an injury when I'm making hard turns, the cushioning is also great, it absorbs a lot of shock when hitting the ground after a rebound, but the shoe does pick up a lot of dust quickly, I'd recommend this shoe for centers/wings.
I had no issues with traction on clean courts. It can occasionally slip on dusty courts.
The herringbone traction pattern allowed me to change directions easily.
It's not very nice indoors. On dusty court, you're going to need to wipe a lot because of the dust pickup. Even on clean courts, I slipped out a lot.
The traction pattern is really solid. I think it's a good setup.
I would say the traction is decent, at best. They weren't great but held up for the most part.
On a clean court, the translucent rubber will stop on a dime. On dusty courts, you will need to wipe from time to time.
I had a pair with an entirely translucent outsole and it picked up a lot of dust. It caused me to slip quite a bit whenever I tried to plant my foot hard on a lot of movements.
This Air Strobel unit doesn't feel quite as nice as the Zoom unit in the KD 14 but feels nice regardless.
The insole feels incredibly comfortable, and the Air Zoom Strobel is bouncy.

The cushioning setup is solid considering the affordable retail price. The Air Strobel gives you a cloudlike feel when you slip on the shoe but the forefoot Zoom unit felt pretty dead and didn't provide a lot of bounce.

The full-length phylon, Air Strobel, and Zoom unit in the forefoot all combine to make the shoe feel very bouncy. The shoe also provides plenty of impact protection, but it doesn't feel very responsive.
The shoe excels in the cushioning department. It feels springy as soon as you put them on.
There is an Air Strobel unit with a Zoom Air unit underneath the forefoot. I couldn't feel the Zoom Air unit at all. Overall, the setup felt firm.
The full-length Phylon midsole with an Air Strobel and a Zoom unit in the forefoot feels very smooth, gives you good impact protection but isn't crazy bouncy.
The full-length Air Strobel board feels cloud-like which is incredible for the price that the Zion comes in at.
The materials feel cheap, and the durability doesn't look the best. It doesn't affect the performance, though.
The materials make the shoe light, strong, and durable. The tongue is a little bit too thin for my liking.
There is no break-in time because the shoe is made of very minimal materials. However, they aren't the best in terms of quality.
Most of the upper are made of fuse and textiles, and they feel like this is where Jordan Brand cut costs.
Screen mesh and synthetic materials make up the majority of the shoe. The materials feel cheap, but they are breathable.
The materials are very, very basic with cheap-feeling Mesh and Fuse overlays for added durability. In terms of performance, they get the job done, however.
The materials are almost identical to those that can be found on the Jordan 34. With the lower price point of the ZIon, the materials make a lot of sense.
The shoe has quite a wide base to provide extra lateral support and stability.
The exaggerated outrigger is one of my favourite features on the shoe. The forefoot is wide, and the shoe has solid stability.
The massive outrigger gives you a lot of stability on cuts and the lockdown keeps your feet in place when changing directions.
I had no issues with support and lockdown. The bottom two lace loops provide a bit of extra support with lateral movements. My only concern is the shoe feels very low and not tight around the ankle.
The lateral side of the shoe helps contain your foot on hard side-to-side movements.
One of the strong suits of the shoe is the support. The shoe is fantastic at preventing you from rolling over.
The internal heel counter is very stiff, rigid, and keeps your heel locked down. I had no side-to-side movement on the footbed and the wide base provides a lot of stability.
I felt insecure in both the heel and the forefoot area. However, the shoe is saved by the midfoot feeling very locked in and the larger-than-average outrigger.
This is not the most comfortable shoe ever, but I never experienced any pain either.
If you like a bit of extra length in your shoe, you could go up half a size.
These have close to a 1-to-1 fit but are a bit more on the snug side when it comes to space in the forefoot area.
The shoe fits well for the most part, but I did have some rubbing in the forefoot area. It wasn't sloppy, and I did feel locked into the shoe.
Overall the fit is pretty good and the materials hug your feet nicely. There is some excess space in the toe box and there is some bubbling if you tie them tightly.
The length of the Jordan Zion 1 is longer than expected. They fit quite long.
The grooves are thick and the rubber is hard. The durability seems good enough for playing outdoors.
The rubber feels hard, and it might perform well outdoors.
The materials break in quite a bit, so you should be fine going true to size.
If you have wider feet, maybe test going half size up.
The shoe feels narrow.
I went true to size and it felt pretty damn good.
I went true to size and had no issues.
I did go true to size.
I went true to size as a slightly wide-footer and felt perfectly fine.
For $90 retail this is a solid pickup. The firm cushioning feels like a downgrade to me, everything else is an upgrade from previous KD Trey 5 models.
The KD Trey 5 IX is a solid performer. This shoe might be for you if you are looking for a lightweight, minimal, and affordable shoe.

This is shoe is solid if your looking for a budget sneaker. The traction is solid, but would not recommend for outdoors. The cushion is solid but not the best. The support is decent but I did roll my ankle a few times in it. The materials are soft and breathable. The shoe does also fit true to size.

The shoe is very comfortable and is great for its price. It has Nike Zoom Air in the soles, which is incredibly comfortable when applying pressure. Material feels somewhat thin but is surprisingly very durable. 8.2/10.
its ok for a first shoe/budget option. Doesnt really lack in anything but doesnt excel in anything either. Really mediocre but when taking into consideration price they are ok.
I had these shoes for 4 months, and they are destroyed, I play 3 times a week, everytime that I play my feets hurts, if you want to buy them think twice.
I love the blue KD Trey 5 IX! They go with my basketball uniform and are super comfortable. These shoes have good grip on the court too!
The traction is really good on clean courts but you'll need to wipe on dusty courts because dust gets stuck in the traction pattern.
On clean courts, you get a nice, solid bite. On dustier courts, the traction wasn't as nice. Even wiping a lot I didn't get the performance I wanted.
The full-length Review cushioning feels firmer than previous KD Trey 5 models. The forefoot Zoom unit is barely noticeable.
The full-length Review cushioning is pretty soft and offers better impact protection than Phylon. The forefoot Zoom unit offers a nice subtle bounce. The cushioning is my favorite part of this shoe.
The upper materials are actually pretty nice considering the budget price.
The textile materials feel soft, supportive, and conform well to your feet. Considering the budget price, the materials are pretty damn nice!
The heel counter locked down my feet securely, I didn't experience any side-to-side movement on the footbed, and the wide base offers solid lateral stability.
Lateral support and containment were good for me, but if you are a big guy these might not be supportive enough.
The upper hugged my feet really nicely and I didn't have any dead space in the toe box.
The padding in the heel is pretty minimal which led to a little bit of heel slippage for me.
The traction was solid on outdoor courts and the rubber held up pretty well.
The width is normal, which is weird for KDs that are usually rather narrow.
Runs a little bit long.

The Adidas N3XT L3V3L is a good performer and I enjoyed playing in them. They are pretty expensive at $180 though, and they didn't perform well enough to crack my rotation. They also aren't the best for guards because they're pretty bottom-heavy.
The Adidas N3XT L3V3L Futurenatural is a tremendous step forward for laceless performance shoes. The only obvious downside that I experienced was the weight of the shoe.
If you've ever tried the N3XT L3V3L line you know what to expect performance-wise with these. For $180, I probably wouldn't recommend them because of the price and the stiff cushion setup.
The Adidas N3XT L3V3L Futurenatural almost feels like the laceless version of the Harden Vol. 5, but with slightly better materials and a laceless upper.

The traction could be better ir fails on Dusty courts, cushion could be better also, support amazing, ir fire perfectly when you put it. The big down is the weight, its very heavy so its not made for guards. Overall good shoe.
The traction is pretty solid, but I did slip out a few times. However, I think this is mostly just because of the way I play with not planting the center of my foot on hard moves.
The traction suctions down really well on surfaces like hardwood. It also performs well on most outdoor courts as long as the surface isn't slick.
This outsole pattern is very similar to the Harden Vol. 5 and offers pretty good traction. On clean courts I had no problems, but with any dust I had to consistently wipe to avoid slipping out.

I liked the cushion set up a little better compared to the Harden 5 even though it uses the same tech. The Boost foam felt bouncy with nice underfoot cushioning and a decent court feel. Overall, I enjoyed this cushion setup.
The shoe features a drop-in midsole comprised of Boot, Lightstrike, and a soft flange that comes up the side of the shoe. This shoe is a beast at storing potential energy and rapidly releasing it.

The full-length Boost drop-in midsole with Lightstrike was a better implementation than the Vol. 5 as well. I could feel the Boost a little bit, but they definitely don't have good impact protection. The setup is very responsive with excellent court feel.
Boost and Lightstrike combine to provide a mixture of comfort and stability. It feels responsive and has a bit of impact protection.
The materials are very nice! The screen mesh upper is quite thin and very supportive. The knit around the ankle is stretchy and feels great. Overall, the materials feel very premium.
The upper is a dual-layer setup that uses thick padding. The heel pods also hold your foot into the shoe really well.
The Primeknit upper is really nice and the materials overall are very premium. Nothing to complain about here!
This shoe is made of almost all the exact same materials as the Adidas Harden Vol. 5.
I had no issues - heel lockdown, lateral support, and containment are all very nice.

I didn't have any issues with support in these. The Achilles pillows are really nice and I experienced no side-to-side movement on the footbed. Lateral stability was also nice because of the really wide base.
The added stripes that cover the forefoot do a solid job of helping to keep your foot contained.
The fit is very snug, especially in the toe box. The only issue I had was these were very hard to take on and off.
The padding mentioned earlier sucks down on your foot to keep you secure. The shoe really fits the foot well.
The fit is great, but they are really hard to put on and take off. Make sure you get the right size because the lack of laces means you can't adjust the fit at all.
The Futurenatural process of making the shoe feel as close to the foot as possible gives you more freedom to move around in the shoe.
Durability is alright.
The durability is in the middle of the pack for outdoor shoes but pretty good for basketball shoes.
If you have really wide feet you may want to stay away from these.
This shoe fits snugger than the Harden Vol. 5.
These shoes accommodate just about every shape of feet. I would recommend going true to size.
I recommend going down half a size.
I would recommend going half a size down.

The Nike KD 14 is one of the best shoes of 2021 so far. The cushion feels like a springy marshmallow, the traction was fantastic, the support and lockdown were great. The shoe does everything well from a performance basketball perspective.

Every aspect of the KD14 performs really well and I like it better than the KD13. The cushion feels awesome and the traction and fit work well after a short break-in period. Also, the $150 price is fair considering all the tech you are getting.
