I promise you will not get disappointed if you pick the Dame 5. If the cushioning was a little softer and the traction a little better on dusty courts, this shoe might have received the first ever perfect rating from me.
This is the best Dame shoe yet and that is saying a lot! The Dame 5 combines the best categories of the previous models and gives us a shoe that any player can wear and feel strong.
The Dame 5 is solid all the way around: great traction, great cushion, superior lockdown, wonderful support, and stability.
At $115, the Dame 5 is a very good performance basketball shoe. The traction took a while to break in, but other than that, everything about this shoe is really nice.
The Adidas Dame 5 is an incredible shoe. The Bounce cushioning is absolutely amazing and the herringbone traction pattern is close to perfect.
Get the basics down and you have a great shoe. Thank you Adidas and Dame! This is the best Dame ever, as Adidas finally found the right combo of everything, especially traction.

I really enjoyed playing in the Dame 5 on clean courts. The cushion is pretty damn nice, materials are nice, fit is good and it's also very supportive. This is a solid performer at a very fair price. Just make sure you don't get the translucent rubber versions if you plan to play on dusty courts.

I've had them for almost 4 months now, and I got them with the pure intention of playing outside basketball. They've held up perfectly. Not a single scratch, and I've played under some rough conditions.  The shoes require some wiping in case you play on sandy courts, but otherwise the traction is great. There is some dead space in the front of the shoe, but once you get used to it, it's actually very comfortable and makes the shoes

The first performance basketball shoes I have acquired being a more or less concsious consumer. Pros include stepping comfort, nice balance between impact protection and court feel and of course the PILLOW PARADISE inside the sneaker. Being a heavy wing type of player I prefer laterally stable shoes with above average impact protection, and Dame 5 deliver that. Impact protection is not sufficient on the outdoor surfaces though. Questionable grip for translucent outsoles.

I was very disappointed with them. I came from the best shoe I ever had (dame 4) and decided to try the next chapter on the dame series, but oh my. Materials were kind of cheap and the traction was worst than the 4s. Ankle support was good tho. First try I used them outside, and some of the materials from the top broke because of my change of directions. Decent performer but disappointing knowing the previous Dame 4. It’s not even a good-looking shoe.

Phenomenal support with and wide base and stable cushioning. The traction on dusty indoor courts is not great, so I ultimately began using these as my go-to outdoor shoes and they have been amazing for that. The rubber grips surfaced, concrete, and asphalt outdoor courts really well.
The most comfortable shoe I’ve
The traction on the Dame 5 is money! It's squeaky, it's got the grip and it let's you stop on a dime. On dusty courts, there are slight slipping problems.
The fairly wide and deep herringbone pattern grips on every move and lets me accelerate quickly with no slips.
The herringbone traction is thick and widely spaced apart. It worked well on all courts and picked up very little dust.
Adidas is sticking to traditional herringbone traction pattern. The traction takes a little time to break in and can be problematic on dusty courts. On clean courts, you will be stopping on a dime!
Multi-directional herringbone with thick and wide grooves. If it ain't broke, don't fix it.
The traction worked great when clean or freshly wiped with some occasional wiping on dusty floors.
On clean courts, you have a really, really nice stop! But on dusty courts it is horrible. The colorways with translucent rubber pick up dust like crazy.
Full-length Bounce cushioning feels low-to-the-ground, responsive and springy. I would have liked a little more cushioning in the forefoot though.
The Bounce cushioning is thick, bouncy, quick and responsive. I especially love the smooth heel-to-toe transition.
I absolutely love the ride that thicker Bounce cushioning of the Dame 5 provides.
I really like the Bounce cushioning because it provides a lot of court feel and responsiveness while also providing good impact protection.
The Bounce cushioning is our favorite part of the Dame 5. Response, comfort, durability, it's all taken care off.
The cushioning is a nice blend of court feel and impact protection.

Court feel is really good, the heel has a nice bounce and the heel-to-toe transition is great. Overall, this is a nice combination of responsiveness and impact protection that should work well, especially for guards.
The materials are nice and soft and feel great on your feet.
I am not a big fan of the felt/suede material.
There are Mesh and leather colorways but the materials don't exactly feel premium on either one. They perform without any problems though.
The performance of the materials works fine, but I am not a fan of how the felt material used on my colorway looks and feels.
Materials are soft, breathable, flexible and comfortable. Everything you want out of basketball shoe materials!
Mesh and some suede or synthetic suede. Not bad I guess if you’re looking for value.
Overall, the materials feel nice on-foot but don't exactly look or feel premium.
The support on the Dame 5 is great thanks to the wide base, Achilles pillows and TPU caging on the lateral side.
The support is based primarily on the lacing system and the TPU lateral support wing.
The lockdown is amazing, and your feet sit deep in the midsole of the wide base which gives you unmatched stability.
I think the support in the Dame 5 is phenomenal! No side-to-side movement, no heel slippage, and your feet are sitting slightly inside the Bounce cushioning which provides great containment.

With soft and flexible materials like in the Dame, support can't be a 10/10. But the internal heel counter, wide base, and lateral TPU overlay keep you on the footbed and prevent any heel slippage or sliding.
Stability is excellent with a low to the ground set up and very wide outsole.
The TPU caging on the lateral side keeps you on the footbed, the lateral outrigger keeps you stable, and several Achilles pillows make sure that there is no heel slip.
These shoes are insanely comfortable!
Probably the best-fitting Dame shoe so far. The materials are soft and comfortable and the lacing system does a great job locking down your feet.
The lacing system and internal padding give you an amazing lockdown.
Your foot is locked down perfectly by the lacing system, but there is a little bit of dead space in the toe box.
The fit is snug, secure and soft. What more do you want?
No heel slip, side to side movement, or banging of the toes.
The fit is pretty nice except a little bit of dead space in the toe box.
Outdoors - you will be good to go!
The rubber is pretty hard and thick and I didn't experience any fraying - so outdoors should be good.
Slight wide-footers can go down half a size like everybody else. If you have very wide feet then stay true to size.
The fit is a little bit on the narrow side.
Go down half a size.
True to size.
These run long so I’d advise half a size down for everyone but the maybe widest of wide footers.
The Dame 5 runs super long. Go down half a size, if you have narrow feet you could even go down a full size.
This is a solid, solid performer, especially at the price of $110. The traction is excellent, the cushioning is soft, and the materials are pretty nice and comfortable.
The traction on this shoe is absolutely awesome and the Micro G cushioning feels really good. Unfortunately, the fit wasn't perfect for my feet.
For $110 you really can't go wrong with the Anatomix Spawn Low. It doesn't have the big-name brand attached, and the looks might not be amazing, but the performance is top notch!
If you are looking for a low, fast, cushioned ride that will draw some attention for the looks and colors, the Anatomix Spawn is it.

Even though this shoe has very little in common with its predecessors, it performs very well all around with excellent traction and a pretty good fit if you ignore the bubbles in the forefoot. I prefer these over the Curry 6 when it comes to performance.
This is my favorite Under Armour shoe so far! I love the fit, the Micro G cushioning, and the excellent traction.

I personally really liked these shoes. They gripped incredibly, and i quite literally never slipped. The cushion is nice and plush, yet reactive which is great for guards who want comfy cushion. The issue is with the way the upper is built. The materials bunch up in the forefoot and cause a pinching sensation that isn’t the nicest but wearing thick socks improved it. All in all, great shoes for indoor players who rarely go on outdoor courts.
Micro G at its best ! Very bouncy, very reactive with no lack of impact protection.
The traction has a crazy, crazy hard bite!
Traction was beastly. Straight up beastly.
The traction is freaking insane! Whether I played on a clean court, or on a dusty court, there were no problems at all!
On all courts, the Spawn locked it down with no slipping at all!
The traction is definitely the highlight of the shoe.
Everything about the traction pattern is A1. Requires very little wiping, even on dusty courts.
The Micro G feels a lot firmer than we are used too from the Clutchfit Drive or the original Spawn. I like the balance between impact protection, court feel, and response.
The Micro G cushion is well-balanced offering court feel and impact protection.
I kinda like the firmer Micro G. It's still soft, but not mushy and gives you a great balance between impact protection and court feel.
Impact protection is outstanding and court feel is really nice and quick.
This version of Micro G slightly firmer than stock Micro G and a good blend of court feel, impact protection, and bounce.
The MicroG cushioning provides a lot of court feel in the forefoot and impact protection in the heel. It also doesn't bottom out which makes it very durable.
The foam-backed mesh is soft and pliable. Doesn't feel very premium in-hand but is very comfortable on-foot.
The lightweight mesh offers support right where you need it and flex where you’d want it.
The mesh materials don't feel premium but they definitely get the job done!
Not the most premium feel in-hand, but the materials work well on-foot.
I don't care about materials but the materials of the original Under Armour Spawn look and feel far more premium. However, this version of the Spawn is far more plush and layered.
Break-in time is close to zero.
Lateral containment is good and the lacing system gives you a lot of flexibility to achieve great lockdown even when you have narrow feet.
Support is pretty standard.
The support in the Anatomix Spawn is phenomenal. No heel slippage or side-to-side movement.
Midfoot shank. Wide base. Wide lacing. Lateral wing tied into the lacing system. NO OUTRIGGER, but no problem.
Stability is great with a nice flat outsole and wide forefoot.
Support was very solid for a low-top shoe with minimal material usage.
Not as easy to put on as many other modern hoops shoes, but overall, the fit is pretty nice.
There was some unwanted dead space in the toe box.
I experienced some irritation of a rubber piece digging into my forefoot in the beginning, but overall the fit is pretty nice.
The fit isn't bad, but it's confusing. The toe-box and midfoot are a little too wide for my feet but the heel is narrow.
No movement side to side and almost zero heel slip out of the box.
The padding and the lacing system feel really nice and provide great lockdown.
The rubber is very soft and pliable, don't play outdoors!
The rubber starts fraying quickly, not recommended for outdoor use.
Not recommended for outdoor use.
The traction pattern is wearing out quickly, not recommended for outdoor use.
I didn't have any issues with the width as a slightly wide-footer.
I'd suggest going down half a size.
I think most everyone can go true to size comfortably.
True to size.
Even though this isn't really a performance upgrade to the Kobe 4, this is still a really good performance shoe. However, I don't think they are worth $175.
I love that Nike didn’t change a thing. And why should they when it’s one of the best low tops of all time?
This shoe feels more Retro than Protro. They will probably make it into my rotation, but the price of $175 is pretty steep.

The Nike Kobe 4 is one of the greatest basketball shoes of all-time but I expected the inclusion of forefoot cushion for a performance-upgraded shoe. For $175 they could have, and should have, given us more.
The Protro 4 is a very solid performer - if you are a Kobe fan get them! But at the price of $175, there are way better shoes out there.
For $175, these feel like a sneaker from 2009 trying to keep up in 2019.

It is a shoe that fits perfectly, it might feel a bit stiff at the start, but once you break in the leather starts working its magic and it FITS like a glove. The cushion is good but only enough for a center. I feel like I would like it to have a bit more like the KD 14's. The durability is okay, I played outdoors with it twice and i see no big wear and tear with my outsole.

Amazing experience playing with these shoes. Would have taken better care of them if I’d knew how rare they rare. Unfortunately after playing with them outdoors the lower outer part of the shoe laces got ripped off after a year or so :(
This shoe is what i wanted because it has amazing traction&cushion good fit&materials overall i recommend this shoe
Love the shoe, the air unit on the heel you can feel I wish that it had more durability
Not a bad shoe but not the best Kobe shoe but again it's not bad
The traction is aggressive and works well. Some wiping is needed on dusty courts.
This herringbone traction pattern is just about as perfect as you can get.
Most Kobes have a crazy bite, but these were a little disappointing on dusty courts.
The Kobe 4 Protro offers the same pattern and the same soft bite as the original Kobe 4.
The traction was a little iffy at first, but after the break-in period, it was really nice.
The traction is amazing!
Springy and bouncy Zoom in the heel and soft and responsive in the forefoot.
Heel Zoom is fantastic and can be felt from day one.  I didn’t have any issues at with the forefoot (yet) but I would have loved full-length Zoom.
The Zoom unit in the heel is really nice but the forefoot is pretty dead. I am a big fan of this setup because it's very responsive and low-to-the-ground.
There is a Phylon midsole and a large volume Zoom Air unit in the heel. The setup feels similar to the original but the foam seems to be a bit softer.
Bounce Zoom unit in the heel and firmer Phylon in the forefoot. Nothing to complain, but there are better cushioning setups out there.
The Phylon forefoot and heel Zoom are a little disappointing, especially since Nike promised us full-length Zoom.
We still get synthetic leather and plasticky mid-panels. They absolutely get the job done, but I would have loved an upgrade to the materials.
The materials feel plasticky feel they confirmed to my foot quickly with no hot spots or pinching!
You need to break-in the materials for a little bit. I am not a big fan of synthetic materials but they are super durable and will last for a long time.
It works. It’s durable. It breaks in nicely.
Not exactly the best materials. The synthetic leather starts off really stiff but gets better over time. The durability of the materials will be very good.
The materials perform fine but feel a bit old-fashioned.
Support comes from the excellent fit and heel counter and the stability is excellent thanks to the large outrigger.
This shoe is crazy supportive, no issues with lateral containment or lockdown.
The heel counter, carbon shank, and wide forefoot provide a lot of support and stability.
An external heel counter, lateral outrigger, carbon fiber midfoot shank. Nothing spectacular -  but I didn't have any support issues at all!
The support is really good, especially for a low-top.
The comfort of this shoe is slightly above average. I did have pinching issues around the ankles when lacing them very tightly.
Even half a size up I had zero heel slip no side to side movement and it still fit like a glove.
I did have slight issues with the top eyelet sawing into my ankle bone. But, overall, the fit was pretty good.
The fit is awesome.
The rubber is pretty soft and frays easily.
The fit is not as narrow as I am used to from the Kobe line.
As a slightly wide-footer I experienced a little pinching pain around the forefoot.
I suggest true to size for regular feet and half a size up for wide footers.
Runs a little bit long.
I went true to size.
The Puma Uproar is a fun shoe! If you are looking for a moderately-cushioned shoe with near-perfect lockdown and traction, look no further.
Puma really has impressed me quite a bit. The cushioning could be a little better, but everything else worked perfectly!
I enjoyed playing in these. This shoe is a jack of all trades but master of none.
Initially, I slipped a little bit, but it seemed like the rubber became better the more I played in them.
The Blade traction pattern worked reliably on all courts I played on.
On a clean court, you get good stops and even on dusty courts, it's never horrible. But even if you wipe a lot, you will never feel glued to the floor.
The heel cushioning is nice, but I'd wish there was a little more impact protection in the forefoot.
The cushioning setup is pretty firm and provides a lot of court feel but only very little bounce back.
The cushioning is super firm and compresses very little. Court feel is good and impact protection wasn't horrible, but this shoe just doesn't feel comfortable.
Materials differ from colorway to colorway. I like the synthetic leather/leather materials and old-school construction of the "Palace Guard" colorway.
Once the materials are broken-in you are good to go!
The textile materials and synthetic leather feel cheap in-hand but work well on-foot.
A very stable and supportive shoe thanks to the wide, solid base and the way your feet sit deep in the midsole.
There are heel counters and a stable, wide base for stability - but no outrigger.
I felt very stable and locked down.
The thick foam wraps on the heel and ankle prevent any side-to-side movement or heel slip and the lacing system provides a ton of lockdown.
Lockdown is awesome and the lacing system works perfectly from ankle to forefoot.
No dead space at all!
Should work well outdoors!
Width-wise the fit is normal.
Even ignoring the fast-fit adaptive lacing system - this is a really nice performance basketball shoe. On top of that - this is a real head-turner!
The first-ever self-lacing basketball shoe is here - and it's one of the best basketball shoes we have ever played in.
The Nike Adapt BB is a good performance basketball shoe. But there are better performers for much cheaper. So if you are a sneakerhead, or really into innovative tech, then this is a great shoe!

I had a lot of fun playing in the Nike Adapt BB. The self-lacing system works well and the overall performance is really solid. Pick these up if you are interested in the latest tech and you can afford the hefty price tag!

The circle and lines traction pattern using translucent rubber is screaming loud and works really well on clean courts. On dusty courts, you will need a while to break-in but it never gets really good.
The traction performance is beasty!
Even though the rubber is translucent I found the traction to be rather good. Works very well on clean courts, but dusty courts can be problematic.
The traction is clearly the best performance aspect of the Nike Adapt BB! Squeaky, responsive, but a little inconsistent on dusty courts.
The Cushlon cushioning is super nice. Really nice compression in the heel and super bouncy. The only downside is that you don't get a ton of court feel.
I love the full-length Cushlon cushioning setup, but I would have preferred to see a Lunarlon or React setup.
The full-length Cushlon insole feels super comfortable, especially in the heel! I really like the cushioning setup, but for $350 I had hoped for a little more.
Full-length Cushlon is nice - but not the best cushion system Nike has to offer.
The materials are super nice and feel great on foot.
Nike used some of their best materials, and they all came together really nicely! Light, breathable, flexible and the break-in time is minimal.
The materials look nice and feel really premium.
The materials are soft and supportive.
Support is good overall, but I felt a little bit wobbly because your feet are pretty high off-the-ground.
Outrigger, internal heel counter, external heel clip, and great overall lockdown coming from the lacing system.
I didn't have any heel slippage and no side-to-side movement in the forefoot. The shoe felt a little bit "tippy" at times, mostly because of the soft cushioning.
The support of the Adapt BB is kind of clunky.
The adaptive fit system is insane! Don't worry that you can't get it tight enough - this system will crank your laces tighter than you ever could!
The self-lacing mechanism does an amazing job and remembers the perfect fit. This is really a smart shoe!
The self-adjusting automatic system really works! But you won't be able to customize your fit like you are able with regular laces.
The fit is pretty good for what it is. But I feel that a traditional lacing system allows you to better customize the fit to your feet.
The rubber is super soft, but we didn't experience a lot of fraying.
Would I take this shoe outdoors? No!
Runs a little bit narrow, especially in the forefoot.
Runs true to size.
The Curry 6 is easily the best shoe in the Curry signature line.
I am loving the Curry 6! Definitely the #1 in my rotation right now.
In my opinion, this is the best Curry signature shoe since the Curry 2. Everything about this shoe is great, except the pain I experienced on the top of the feet when cranking the laces tightly.

The Curry 6 is a really fun performer that has everything I want from a basketball shoe: amazing cushion, amazing fit, and while the traction is not quite on Curry 2 level, it is still pretty nice! The durability of the rubber on my pair was an issue though...
The Curry 6 brings a great combo of traction, cushioning and support to make fast basketball player very happy!
This is easily the most well-rounded Curry we’ve had since the 1.

I really enjoy playing in the Curry 6. The cushioning is pretty nice, the traction, fit, support and the minimal upper are really fun. The only problem is the durability of my pair - let's hope the glue work is better on future colorways!
Easily the best Curry signature shoe! The cushioning is amazing, materials are really nice, the traction took care of us, only the support was a little bit of a letdown.
The Curry 6 looks good, has great traction and is very stable, but the constant lace pressure, bad heel fit, and a really dumb outsole design make these far from perfect.

The Under Armour Curry 6 is an amazing shoe for all guards. It is very light and responsive, and it has unbelievable court feel. The traction is amazing, and it is good on dust too! The traction works in all directions. The cushion was pretty good, and it was very responsive with great impact protection. The support was great, and I was locked in! The materials are amazing, and it was very breathable and thin! The durability had some issues, but that was about it. Everything else was phenomenal!

The shoe has ok comfortability and is ok for its price. It doesn't boast any special tech like a massive airsole or anything, but it makes sense as Curry's play style is very shooting-based and not above the rim much. Material feels somewhat thin and has ok durability. 8.0/10.

The Curry 6 is a great shoe. The traction was phenomenal! The cushion in my pair was rock solid and I didn’t enjoy it as much as I wished. However the rest of the shoe checks off all the necessary categories! The Curry 6 is definitely a win!!!
I'm on my 2nd pair and would highly recommend them. Doesn't feel like they have traction at first but once broken in they are a very good shoe
Very good shoes and light for me. I didn't feel like I was bulky. traction is great for both court but you need to wipe it somethime.
The circular traction pattern on the lateral side offers superb multi-directional grip — dust or no dust

Performance is super nice on clean courts - you will stick like glue! Minimal wiping on dusty courts. Durability is bad though - on the second day the rubber started to separate from the midsole. Let's hope that's just a defect of this colorway.
The traction was superb! Dust gets stuck in the grooves on the medial side, but a wipe or two will solve that problem.
The traction performs very well on clean courts but needs some thorough wiping on dustier courts. Unfortunately, the durability of the rubber compound is pretty bad.
On clean and semi-clean courts, these things stick like Gorilla.
The traction has been pretty consistent for me and a pleasant surprise on the court.
The performance of the traction was really good, but the durability is an issue. The rubber frays off easily and the split sole design starts to peel off the outsole after a few weeks.
The traction pattern did its thing, but it did collect a little bit of dust.
Traction is excellent with a great bite on all surfaces with only very occasional wiping.
The full-length HOVR cushioning is softer and more comfortable than previous Curry models.
I love this cushioning setup! Low-profile, great court feel and still pretty comfortable. Major upgrade compared to the Curry 4!
The cushioning is pretty awesome and offers the perfect amount of impact protection and court feel. Overall, the cushioning is a bit on the firm side.
The full-length HOVR cushioning gives you a good balance of impact protection and court feel. In my opinion, this is the best cushioning in a Curry shoe so far.
The cushioning is tuned for optimal impact protection while still keeping you close to the court for those crossovers and step-backs.
The full-length HOVR cushioning isn’t overly soft or overly firm, it felt just right for me
Impact protection is okay, but we expected a little more from the new HOVR cushioning. Works well for quick guards looking for a firm, no-nonsense cushioning.
The HOVR cushioning is very responsive with a lot of court feel and solid impact protection.
A bit disappointing  - the new full-length HOVR cushioning feels the same as older models.
After a short break-in period, the full-length Knit is very comfortable but still strong enough to provide lockdown and support.
The full length knit truly feels like a sock!
The materials are lightweight and breathable, the tongue is soft and stretchy and provides easy entry for your feet. I would have liked a little more padding though.
Knitted materials with fuse overlays in high-wear areas feel nice, but there was some lace pressure if you like to crank the laces.
The full knit upper with elastic areas is much more comfortable than the Curry 4/5 were.
The full knit upper had some areas of minor discomfort in the beginning but became very comfortable after a while.
The thin, stretchy and breathable materials feel really nice once you break them in. There was a bit of lace pressure though.
The full knit upper is very supportive and super comfortable. Minimal break-in time required - that's a first in a Curry sneaker!
The knit materials and fuse underlays feel nice and need no break-in time.
The flat and wide base, TPU counter, and external outrigger provide the excellent stability and support we are used to from the Curry line.
The support is clearly the best feature of the Curry 6. This is probably the most stable shoe I ever played in!
The support is really nice thanks to the full-length speed plate and heel counter.
Like always in the Curry line, the support features are pretty amazing.
The outsole is wide, the midsole is solid and supportive and lateral containment is excellent.
Stability has always been one of the strongest features of Curry signature sneakers - and this hasn't changed in the Curry 6!
Support was really good. The only slight issue is the lateral containment in the front because the knit is really stretchy.
I think this shoe is meant to be worn with an ankle brace.
Stability is excellent thanks to an extra wide and flat outsole.
The fit was a little off in the beginning, but the footbed of the Curry 6 molds to your feet over time and becomes very comfortable.
Fit and lockdown are pretty tricky as I experienced a lot of pain when I laced the shoes too tightly.
The one-bootie upper gives you a pretty good 1:1 fit.
I had to double-sock to keep from having heel slip and forefoot movement.
There was some minor heel slip in the beginning which was easily fixed by a double-sock.
I went down half a size and the fit was awesome for me.
The Curry 6 fits really well! The elastic materials conform to your feet nicely and the lacing system works wonders.
The stiff midsole, wide ankle collar, and top eyelets which are placed too low combined to create heel slip problems for me.
Don't use those outdoors as the rubber will not last very long.
I think the Curry 6 should be fine outdoors.
As a slightly-wide footer, I felt perfectly fine.
Pretty narrow width-wise and snug in the toebox.
The Curry 6 runs a little long but I went true to size.
I went down half a size.
Went down half a size but still had problems with heel slip.
The Why Not Zero.2 is quick, comfortable, supportive, and breaks in quickly.

Traction is superb, materials are 50:50, support is solid, cushioning is responsive in the forefoot and comfortable in the heel. There is nothing bad about the Why Not Zero.2, but there is also nothing phenomenal. Not the best shoe I ever played in but a good performer overall.
I really enjoyed playing in the Jordan Why Not Zero.2. They look great, the price is right, whatever position you play - you are going to enjoy these!
I’ve literally got nothing to complain about with this shoe. Jordan made the Why Not Zero.2 a lot more fun with a bouncier cushioning set-up while keeping the shoe just great all around.
For $125 this is a really nice shoe - highly recommended! The traction and fit are the outstanding features for me.
Overall this shoe is really dope. The only downside is that the traction is a downgrade compared to the first Russell Westbrook sneaker.

I think the Jordan Why Not Zero.2 are a solid performer, and fun to play in. But the hefty materials, the uncomfortableness I experienced in the collar area and the uneven support in the heel to forefoot throw them off.
The cushioning is absolutely amazing and reminds me of the AJ29. This is an amazing overall performer, Russell Westbrook and Jordan Brand should be proud!

Couldn’t figure out what size I should get these in and eventually they ended up being way too long for me to an extent where I always had my socks floating at the front edge of the shoes while playing.
The traction gripped really well, even on dusty courts.
The solid rubber grabs the floor really hard.
The circular traction pattern is freaking amazing and gives you great stopping power on clean courts. On dusty courts, it takes you only a slight wipe from time to time.
Excellent bite right out of the box on all surfaces with very little to no wiping on dusty floors.
The circular pattern gives you coverage in all directions. On dusty courts, you need a slight wipe and you are good to go again.
The traction worked wonders on clean courts, but once the rubber touched dust I was figure-skating.
The traction is one of my favorite features of this shoe. Even on a very dirty middle-school court, the traction is tacky and responsive.
The traction held up well on all courts! Gets the job done, and then some.
The large volume Zoom Air unit in the forefoot provides a lot of impact protection. The heel is just regular Phylon.
No more full-length Zoom, but I am not mad. Forefoot Zoom is nice and there is still a lot of impact protection.
Bouncy in the forefoot and nice compression in the heel. Court feel could be a little better.
The  Zoom feels Zoomy and the injected Phylon feels good underfoot from the get-go.
Decent amount of impact protection in the heel. Very bouncy big-volume Zoom Air unit in the forefoot.
I love the way the cushioning feels. The perfect combination of bounciness and stiffness.
Unlocked Zoom in the forefoot and injected Phylon in the midsole. This is a very robust cushioning setup with a ton of impact protection.
The unlocked Zoom bag feels incredible! Feels back memories of the AJ29.
The mesh and knit materials require zero break-in time and get the job done.
I'm 50:50 when it comes to materials. I like the mesh in the front, but the heel feels bulky and clunky.
The materials are soft and feel really nice on foot.
These materials LOOK way more premium than most shoes in the 140 under range.
Different mesh, fuse, and knit materials feel premium and get the job done.
Materials are a little basic - but they work.
I like the mesh in the forefoot and I think that the thick upper materials will last for a long time.
The textile mesh gets the job done, but takes a while to break in.
Support is good, but not as good as the original.
The lacing system really locks in your feet nicely. The beefy internal heel counter makes sure that there is no heel slip at all.
I would have liked the base to be a little wider to increase stability. Overall, support and lockdown are pretty awesome.
I had zero issues with support and stability and it’s nice to feel some support around my ankles.
No heel slippage, no side-to-side movement. The base isn't very wide and even a little bit rounded, but I never had any problems.
No lateral movements, no heel slippage, and very good lockdown.
The decoupled design of the outsole combined with the narrow and rounded base felt a little too wobbly for me.
The support is solid but nothing about it is outstanding.
The fit isn't as tight or suffocating as in the Why Not Zero.1 and worked fine for me.
The shoe is pretty comfortable overall, but the heel feels a little clunky at times.
The one-bootie construction takes a little to break-in and to get comfortable.
No movement inside the shoe and no heel slip.
The shoe hugs my feet really nicely.
The midfoot and forefoot fit was solid, but the inside collar area was digging into my foot which didn't work out well with my hurt ankle.
The padding and heel counter do a great job, but the fit is a little bit long and wide.
Outdoor courts? Hell no!
The grooves are very malleable and I wouldn't recommend outdoor use.
The fit is pretty narrow and the toe box is rather tight.
I am a slightly wide-footer and I didn't have any problems with these.
The fit is slightly wide.
I went true to size
True to size.
The shoe fits slightly long. Get it a half size-long
I really liked playing in these shoes! If just wished the cushioning was a little more comfortable.
The Nike Kyrie Flytrap 2 is a very solid shoe in most aspects, but cushion could definitely use some improvement.

The support is really nice, and the materials feel pretty good. After wearing the shoe for about 6 months or so the sole of my shoe is pretty destroyed, but it is still easy to play in and really just a good shoe to play in; Inside and outside. It is one of the first basketball shoes I've bought. so I'm pretty new to them.

This shoe has one of the best tractions I've ever played in. It helped me stop on the dime and helped me with my shiftiness. It's also a super lightweight shoe. My only issues are that it is a super narrow shoe and the cushion isn't the best.

It’s not a bad shoe specially for outdoor because the traction is good and the sole is resistant but the cushion is terrible. It feels like you are playing barefoot and it hurts a little when you are running.
These aren’t the worst shoes I have ever bought but far from the best these can be used for young players who are smaller and lighter there would be a good shoe in those cases
I had about 3 pairs of these when I started playing basketball. They are good if you are in need of support and traction. Good for beginner players on a budget.
The traction is sticking like glue! Even dusty courts are not a problem.
It didn’t matter which court I was on, the traction just worked.
The cushioning setup is a no-go if you are looking for impact protection.
If you’re looking for something plush or bouncy then stay away. Far away.
At only $80, the textile materials are pretty awesome.

Your feet are caged nicely, no heel slippage or side-to-side movement at all.
This is a prime example of a mobility shoe and not a stability shoe.

Outdoor should be good because of the hard rubber and deep grooves.

The Wade 7 is a fun shoe to play - definitely recommended!
I am not a big fan of the Wade 7 on-court and I definitely don’t want to play in them again.
On a clean court, the traction is really good. But this shoe attracts a lot of dust and is rather difficult to wipe.
The traction was solid; they do pick up dust on dirtier courts but as long as you keep up on your wipes, you will be fine.
I slipped. Often. Actually, nearly every time I played in them
Impact protection in the heel is really nice and the forefoot feels a little like Boost with a very nice compression. This is one of my favorite cushion setups.
Great impact protection and a very comfortable ride.
The step-in comfort is amazing, but they feel pretty dead under-foot.
The materials look and feel super premium and are comfortable on-foot.
The textile mesh upper wrapped my feet nicely but the synthetic shroud in the forefoot did very little for me.
Materials are nice and well-built.
No heel slippage, perfect lateral containment and very stable.
The shoe makes sure that our foot is secure and glued to the footbed.
Support is good, but the shoe is very stiff because of it.

I went true-to-size and that works for me.

Outdoor use should be good because of the hard rubber.

This might just be the shoe of the year 2018!
The Marquee Boost is a very nice performer at an affordable price - I am impressed!

The most comfortable shoe in the game. Adidas is doing a great job lately!
The Adidas Marquee Boost is definitely one of the more comfortable basketball shoes currently available.
Traction is very nice on clean court, but get you a lot of lateral slippage on dus

Got the low version for outdoor use only. Highly recommended for such a purpose. Boost cushioning just works perfectly fine on harder surfaces. No problems with traction and the outsole is very durable (not translucent, obviously). Overall very solid shoes. Slightly narrow in midfoot area. Minor setbacks - heel area might be slippery inside when using new socks; the top hole for laces would benefit it was plastic/metallic
They wore down much quicker then I had hoped there was some of the fabric on the back started to tear and come off, and after not very long the traction was not very good.
Nice shoes, but the support on lateral movement is not that good. The collar is a nice added protection if you start playing after an ankle injury.
The traction was excellent on clean courts, but I had to wipe the translucent rubber a lot on dusty courts.
No unnecessary storytelling elements, just simple herringbone that works. Well done Adidas!
The traction sticks like glue to clean courts but you need to wipe a lot on dusty courts.

The Boost cushioning setup is everything we love about Boost and suitable for all types of player needs.
Very comfortable Boost cushioning right out of the box. Very similar setup to the Harden V3.
The Boost cushioning is A1!
The Boost setup gives you a nice blend of responsiveness in the forefoot and impact protection in the heel.
Boost id life. Comfortable, responsive, impact protection - this shoe does everything exceptionally well!
Full-length Boost and yes, Boost is still life.
The mix of textile, knit and synthetics feels great in-hand and comfortable on-foot.
The mesh, fuse, and synthetic leather materials look and feel premium.
The materials feel very nice in-hand and perform very well on foot.
The material usage gets the job done but it's not spectacular.
Mesh, textiles, and leather come together to provide an insanely comfortable shoe.
I love the nice mixture of knits, canvas, and micro-molded mesh.
No complaints whatsoever!
The rather stiff ankle collar, midfoot shank, and wide outrigger provide great support and stability.
The thick Achilles padding prevents heel slip. You also get good lateral containment, supportive materials, and a very flat and stable outsole.

The ankle collar of the High version is very firm and supportive but limits your mobility a little bit. I experienced no heel slippage,  no side-to-side movements in the footbed, and great lateral stability.
The snug fit, supportive materials, and the caging of the sole provide very good support.
Outrigger, wide platform for stability, heel counter - everything you need is there!
In the beginning, there was minor heel slip that went away after the break-in period.
No movement inside the shoe no heel slip when I laced to the top, no dead space in the toe box.
No dead space anywhere.
Apart from sizing issues, the fit is pretty nice.
The Marquee Boost takes almost no break-in time and conforms very well to your feet.
The toe area flexes weird and I experienced the dreaded “heel slip” upon my first wears.

Outdoors you are good to go!

Go down half a size!
Runs a little bit long.
The Marquee Boost runs very long. I went down half a size but I think I could have gone down a full size.
Adidas really knocked this one out of the park. Really fun to play in!
Adidas has made a really, REALLY fun shoe. Luckily, the price matched the performance and was truly… N3XT L3V3L.
I really, really want to like this shoe, but traction is the most important aspect for me, and the Adidas Next Level didn't work on dusty courts. On clean courts, I liked it a lot!

Due to insane pricing I almost missed on these shoes but was able to find them later in a questionable olive colorway. Probably my favorite ball shoes so far. The first implementation of Lightstrike in basketball and arguably still the best one. The support and stability are surprisingly good, the chassis is very stable. Never experienced problems with traction. The overall comfort is tremendous. Enjoyed playing outdoors once but both upper and outsole are strictly forbidden to be used there.
The shoe was great, It was the traction that killed the 10.0 overall from my view
It's different! Awesome model from adidas. Great traction.
On clean courts, you will have no problems at all! On dusty courts you need to wipe a lot, otherwise, you will be slipping on lateral as well as linear movements.
Super-grippy on clean and semi-clean courts but you need to wipe a lot on dusty courts.

Multidirectional herringbone. If it's not broke - don't fix it!

It's really crazy how much court-feel and responsiveness you get out of the new Lightstrike cushioning without your feet feeling dead after a long basketball session.
The Lightstrike cushioning is a good middle ground between the softer Boost technology and the responsive Adidas Bounce.

The Lightstrike cushioning took us by storm. It's ridiculously responsive, comfortable and durable.
The Lightstrike foam is the highlight of the shoe and is very comfortable right out of the box.
The full Primeknit upper feels amazing. The inside is nylon-backed to give you additional stability and support.

It’s comfortable, it’s Primeknitish and it’s stretchy.
There is no heel slippage, no side-to-side movement and a lot of support on lateral cuts.
All in all, for a shoe with no laces, support is surprisingly good.
Even though there are no laces, support was really good. Lateral containment is solid, there is absolutely no heel slippage, and the wide base offers a lot of stability.
The outrigger, internal heel counter, TPU lateral barrier and the lockdown of the upper material provided great support.
Stability is very nice with a low to ground cushioning set up and a nice wide outsole.
There are no laces in this shoe but Adidas absolutely killed it! Almost feels like a second skin.

The fit starts off extremely tight, but once it breaks in it conforms really nicely to your feet. We feared that the shoe would become too loose after a while, but that wasn't the case. Only downside: this shoe is incredibly hard to put on.
Heel slip was horrible in the beginning but got a little better over time. Overall, the fit feels great stationary but during play, not so much.
The rubber is really soft so I wouldn't recommend this shoe for outdoor use.
This shoe is slightly narrow but materials will stretch out a little over time.
Starts off really tightly.
These fit like a sock with a sole with no dead space at all.
Go true to your Adidas size (1/2 half size down from Nike)
True to size.
Like most Adidas, I could have gone half a size down if I wanted to.

I really enjoy playing in this shoe because it does everything well. I especially love the cushioning set up, traction, and as shallow as this sounds, its looks.

I was super-impressed by the performance of the T-Mac Millenium. Much better than the original T-Mac! This is a very durable shoe, that should work well for big guys who need a lot of support and cushioning.

Fantastic shoe, incredible in every category. Traction almost perfect (incredibly minimal dust pickup), cushion amazing (bouncy, responsive everything you need in a cushion setup), support amazing, fit (very good 1:1 fit), same thing with sizing. Just buy it, believe in me!!!
I was pleasantly surprised. Whether I was playing on clean or dusty courts, I didn't have any problems.

Great stopping power and almost no wiping needed.

As always, Boost feels great with no lag in the forefoot.
Awesome cushioning! Feels similar to the Marquee Boost.

Slightly narrow.

Works well on clean courts, but dusty courts are super slippery.

Support and lockdown are A+!

I really like the Nike Zoom Air Turbo and the Flytrap shroud. The Kyrie 5 is an upgrade over the Kyrie 4 and works best for quick players who prefer court feel over soft cushioning.
I love these! If you liked the Kyrie 2 or 4, then you are going to love the Kyrie 5.
The Nike Kyrie 5 offers plenty of court feel, a little bit of cushion, great lockdown and aggressive traction wrapped up in a lightweight package.
The Kyrie 5 is a fun shoe that caters to the needs of those that play a more grounded game and require unrestricted mobility.
This is a very good shoe that does everything well with great traction, fit, and decent cushioning.
The Kyrie 5 is a very solid shoe. The main pros are lockdown and court feel, cons are the cushioning of the outsole and the lacking padding of the inner material.

This shoe has been my only pair of indoor basketball shoes and have never failed me once. Traction is great, very durable and relatively clean with just the wipe of the hand. Only thing is the breathability in it, but I don't really care about that too much.

en canchas sucias se resbala bastante, pero solo es limpiar otra vez la suela y se llena de polvo, la amortiguación siento que falta algo para que sea completo, el fit recomiendo subirlo media talla si tienes pie ancho, agarra muy bien el tobillo.
A great shoe with a low to ground feel and play. The only thing is I sometimes rip my achilles on the heel. Above ankle socks aren't even safe, gotta go crew.
Pretty good shoe for point guards , you’ll ,it’s a good shoe if your a ankle snatcher but I advice kyrie 6 is much better
Like any sneaker, you’ll need to swipe now and then for maximum grip, but the traction is excellent right out of the box!

The Air Zoom Turbo bag is truly outstanding, and responsive from any angle. This may very well be my new favorite cushioning from Nike.
The cushioning feels very similar to the Kyrie 4. Very low-to-the-ground, responsive with great heel-to-toe-transition.

Solid impact protection, nice heel-to-toe transition, and bouncy feel of the Nike Zoom Air in the forefoot. Overall, the setup is rather stiff and responsive like we are used to from Kyrie signature models.

The engineered mesh feels really nice and needs very little break-in time.

Top of my foot felt snug and secure but not restrictive.

The Puma Clyde Court Disrupt wound up being one of the more fun models to play in this year (so far).   Not in the Top 5 discussion but you receive solid performance and cushion for the price.
The Puma Clyde Court Disrupt is a very vibrant and well-rounded sneaker. I really like them and I am pleasantly surprised by their performance.
Overall the Puma Clyde Court is a really fun shoe to play in. Great job by Puma!

It's really impressive what Puma was able to do in their first basketball sneaker in a long time. The materials and fit are absolutely A1, the support and traction, however,  could use a little tweaking.
The performance is middle of the road. They won't stay in my rotation but they might work well as a big-man shoe or as an outdoor shoe.
I am very impressed by the first hoops shoe by Puma after their comeback to basketball. The cushioning and traction could be a little better, but everything else was great!
The Puma Clyde Court Disrupt is a great first impression for Puma's relaunched basketball division.
Welcome back Puma! This is a strong shoe that is only let down by the lacking ankle support and bad traction on dusty courts.

These shoes look and feel amazing. The materials soft and premium, unlike anything else for the price. On foot, the cushion setup did not feel very soft or bouncy but it was very responsive. On clean courts, after some break in time, the traction was good. They did, however, pick up dust rather quickly so I had to wipe them a lot. After about a year of playing in them the outsole was only minimally fraying around the heel and forefoot.

The Puma Clyde Court Disrupt was actually WAY better than I thought it would be by having tolerable traction and cushion, really comfortable and durable material, and good fit overall. In the end, I recommend this shoe for hoopers of any play style.
The outsole gripped most of the courts I played on really well.
The traction allowed me to move, cut and defend well.
The traction was super solid on clean courts, but on dusty courts, you will need to wipe a bit more than you would want to.
Traction is very inconsistent, be prepared to wipe a lot.
On dusty courts, you will need to wipe a lot, other than that, traction is pretty good.
The traction takes a while to break in but then it's solid.
I found the traction to be a strong point.
The throwback design of the outsole looks nice but didn't get the job done on dusty courts. I had to wipe every time I transitioned from defense to offense.
A ton of impact protection with good court feel. I would have liked a little more feedback.
Very responsive and bouncy feel, but a lot less court feel than other shoes. The heel-to-toe transition is surprisingly good.
The cushioning reminded me of Adidas Bounce technology with a little less responsiveness and court feel. The impact protection is outstanding.
I was not expecting so much court feel from this cushioning setup. I would have loved a little more bounce-back.

The foam in the cushioning is caged by a super thick rubber which leads to a clunky heel-to-toe transition. Impact protection is decent, but the court feel is not great because you are very high-off-the-ground.

I liked the cushioning a lot! Feels like something in-between Adidas Boost and Adidas Bounce cushioning with a nice mixture of responsiveness and comfort. Unfortunately, it started bottoming out quickly.
The cushioning doesn’t feel fast, dynamic, or responsive at game speed. On the bright side - the court feel is top-notch!
The cushioning was very comfortable and plush, I would have liked a little more court feel though.
I enjoyed the good-looking, durable, and supportive knit upper.
The sock-like knit upper is comfortable, durable and flexible.
The stretchy upper materials are very comfortable.
Materials look premium and feel comfortable on-foot.
The materials are soft, flexible and durable.
The knit upper is flexible and supportive and I like the retro hints of leather.
The heel counter and lacing system worked well and the tooling is firm, flat, and extremely stable.
The support was surprisingly good considering the knit upper. Lockdown was great too.
Support was solid because of the wide base, heel counter and, the supportive rubber in the midsole.
Puma sacrificed some support in exchange for comfort which will probably not work for some more explosive players.
Support and lockdown are great!
The perfect combination of support and flexibility.
My foot was held securely over the footbed for a confident ride.
This shoe is best worn with an ankle brace.
Lockdown was a pleasant surprise, but I would have preferred the forefoot to be a little more snug.
The shoe snapped to my feet perfectly.

Normal to a touch wide.
This shoe caters very well to wide-footers.

The traction and cushion are very solid but the FastFit lacing system has room for improvement and may throw some people off.
We love the new FastFit lacing system. The Air Jordan 33 will definitely be in my rotation even though it is a bit heavy and clunky.
The Air Jordan 33 is a great shoe, especially for big guys looking for impact protection and support. Quick guards looking for a light and minimal shoe should look elsewhere.
Even at the hefty price of $175, I really enjoyed playing in these. The AIr Jordan 33 is a great performer that really stands out on the court thanks to the fast-fit lacing system.
I can't recommend the Air Jordan 33 because they never really broke in for me. The midsole remained extremely stiff and uncomfortable, even after 30 hours of 5 vs 5 play.

Overall, the Air Jordan 33 is a good shoe if you love the looks and the innovative sneaker tech. It performs well in almost every aspect but I think $175 is too expensive for what you get. $130 would be a much fairer retail price.
The Fast Fit system is no gimmick, the support is great, but the materials are a letdown - there are just too many!
I am very disappointed in the Air Jordan 33. The traction is inconsistent, the materials are subpar and the comfort is a disaster!
The Air Jordan 33 bit the floor nicely and loud as hell.
The traction was amazing on lateral movements but slightly slippery on linear movements.
Works well on clean courts but dusty courts are problematic.
Super loud and one of the best traction patterns I've experienced in any Jordan model.
The traction is snappy, responsive, and works reliably -  even on dusty courts.
The micro tread pattern does well, especially when clean or freshly wiped.
Traction was inconsistent on dusty courts.
Loud, squeaking traction that does a good job on lateral moves, but I slipped a lot going in straight lines or planting for jumps.
The Hex Zoom in the heel and unlocked Zoom Air in the forefoot take a little to break-in but provide a nice little extra spring to your step.
Court feel is okay, impact protection is pretty good, and there is a lot of responsiveness.
The great big slab of Zoom Air in the forefoot and the hex unit in the heel provide perfect impact protection once the firm Phylon carrier is broken in.
After breaking in the midsole you get a really nice response from the unlocked Zoom bag in the forefoot. The heel is a little dead and overall the setup feels a bit clunky.
The forefoot unlocked Zoom Air is bouncy and explosive.
If you can't feel the very large forefoot zoom you should get your nerve endings checked!
The big Zoom unit in the front is great, but the heel-to-toe transition is very clunky.
The Zoom Units are responsive but the outsole is crazy stiff and takes forever to break-in.
Unlike the Air Jordan 32, the textile here is much lighter, thinner, and more breathable.
The materials are very thin, soft and pliable.
The mesh/fuse construction doesn't provide the premium look and feel we're used to from Air Jordan but the materials get the job done.
The materials feel really premium, look good, and perform well!
The materials get the job done, but for $185, I would have liked more premium materials.
Nothing to see here but Mesh. If you’re big on value and how luxurious a shoe feels, look elsewhere.
Every material on their own is fine, but there is just too much going on which leads to unnecessary weight and a clunky feel.
The materials aren't very premium and they don't feel the best.
Despite being laceless, the Air Jordan 33 easily keeps you on the footbed and locks your heel down tightly. The midfoot torsion support is a bit much in the beginning but breaks-in nicely.
Amazing lockdown and great stability.
The Jordan XXXIII is easily the most supportive, structured shoe on the market today from a major brand.
I never had any heel slippage or side-to-side movement. Lateral movements are no problem either, thanks to the wide and stable base.
The hidden speed plate provides very good midfoot support and the flat and somewhat wide outsole provides you with a lot of stability.
Makes you feel locked-in and locked down!
The FastFit lacing system provides great lockdown, but I would have still preferred a more customizable traditional lacing system.
The standout of the Air Jordan 33 is the FastFit lacing system: Does it work? Yes. It actually does. Is it perfect? No.
Super snug fit with very little dead space. The Fast Fit lacing system works like a charm and gives you crazy lockdown.
The lockdown is complete and total – you will have NO heel slip or lateral movement.
The fast-fit lacing system is awesome and provides great fit.

The new lacing system works fine and provided good lockdown around the fore- and midfoot, but the ankle collar was a little too loose for my liking. The stiff midsole never really broke-in and was very uncomfortable during longer playing sessions.
I had no issues side to side or front to back because the lacing system just works.
The Fast Fit laceless lacing system works well and the half-boot construction feels great.
The shoe is really snug at first and it takes a little while to get used to the fit. Not very comfortable overall.
Very hard rubber and deep grooves - should be okay outdoors.
Big fat no because of the translucent rubber.

This is the best performer of 2018. I am going to get five pairs of these!
The performance of the Adidas Harden Volume 3 on the court is nearly perfect. It's a special shoe in that it's so simple that it does everything right!
This is the best Harden we have seen so far. Works for players at any position who enjoy freedom of movement, court feel with above-average impact protection, and a great fit.
This is by far the best shoe in the Harden signature series. Pretty much everything was improved - I especially like the cushioning and materials.
Definitely an upgrade over the Harden 2. This shoe has pretty much everything I want in a performance sneaker!
The Harden 3 is a standout when it comes to performance! It checks all the boxes for comfort and fit and does so at a relatively affordable $140 price point.
Great traction, pretty good fit and fun Boost cushioning - sign me up! I’m going to give this a first-team rating.
Fit and cushion are awesome, but the traction was a little too inconsistent and the support a little too low.

Best shoe I've had, even after years of hard wear and play. Cushion is super sweet, has a nice balanced feel that makes you feel quick and snappy. The grip is mint, support is excellent and the materials are nice as well. The perfect example of not doing too much with a shoe yet still reaping the performance benefits. One of the all time greatest Adidas hoop shoes, Hardens haven't been this good since. A shoe everyone can enjoy no matter your dimensions or athletic abilities.

This shoes proves that basketball shoes was never about smashing the best material together, you just need everything to be spot on. My only real problem with this shoe is that although it obviously feature boost, it doesnt provide the soft feel that I prefer, instead it provide decent court feel, even though I personally dont prefer it, for those who prefer court feel this one should do it.
I've been playing on these for about 3 years and it's still holding up pretty good. On dusty courts this are still very squeaky but you will a lil slipping but on a clean court it's very good
One of the best traction shoes I’ve ever had. Almost a perfect performer in general, especially for point guards. Just watch out for the impact protection.
Really amazing sneakers!  best basketball shoes I have, better than newer models! durability, traction, cushioning... perfect for all courts.
The herringbone traction is insane! Dust is only a very minimal problem.
On clean courts, the traction was nothing short of awesome. On dusty courts, you will need to wipe occasionally.
The traditional herringbone pattern worked well on all courts I played on.
Superb traction!
The traction is freaking amazing!
When the sole is clean, grip is fantastic, but it has a tendency to pick up dust fast.
Adidas went with traditional herringbone set up and it’s easily the best traction on a Harden yet.
The translucent rubber on our colorway didn't pick up too much dust on our dirty courts and got the job done. There were some inconsistencies that prevented a better score.
The Boost cushioning isn't caged as much as in the previous Harden models. It provides great impact protection while still being responsive. This is my favorite cushioning setups!
It’s not too bouncy. It’s not too firm. It’s just right - this is my favorite version of Boost in basketball.
The Boost cushioning is less pronounced than in the Harden Vol. 2 but provides a better balance between court feel and impact protection.
Good court feel, good impact protection and the Boost cushioning feels amazing!
Good amount of bounce in the heel and more responsiveness in the front. I really enjoy the Boost cushioning!
This is the best use of the Boost foam yet when it comes to basketball.
The cushioning provides a nice balance of comfort, court feel, springiness, and fun.
The Boost cushioning is a little lower than in the Harden Vol.2 which makes the shoe lighter and gives you better court feel. Impact protection is still there.
The materials are very soft, look and feel premium and provide great lockdown and stability.
The thick and strong materials feel great on-foot.
The textile upper with synthetic overlay is comfortable and pliable out of the box.
The materials are very lightweight and feel great. Very soft and flexible!
The materials feel really nice and do a great job. The shoe gets really hot after playing a while.
Basic "textile" materials that feel somewhat premium.
The materials are super comfortable but stretch out a little too easily.
Lateral containment is very good, the materials are supportive and the base is pretty wide and stable.
The support works perfectly well.
The materials do a fantastic job with lockdown, the caging of the Boost provides stability and acts as an outrigger and the fantastic fit does the rest.
Much more stable than previous Harden models.
Nice lateral containment, stable base and the heel slippage went away after the break-in period.
The cut, combined with perfectly molded collar padding, held my heel in place exceptionally well, providing optimal ankle stability.
Excellent stability, great midfoot support, and good containment.
There was too much freedom of movement in the ankle for my liking.
The fit was very nice for my feet with no dead space at all!
These have been the best fitting Adidas shoes I’ve worn in quite some time.
The lacing system lets you adjust the fit however you like it.
Comfy as hell!
The fit is really comfortable.
There’s something very satisfying about the way the shoe cinches around the foot.
No side to side movement and some very very minor heel slip
The fit works perfectly fine for all type of feet.
The rubber is pretty soft. You better stay away from outdoor use.
I am a slightly wide footer and the fit is perfectly nice for me.
The Harden Vol.3 adapts perfectly to your feet.
Go down half a size.
I recommend going down half a size.
The Anta KT4 is a ton of fun to play in. You’ve got to try them for yourself.
Overall, the Anta KT4 is one of the best performing sneakers available. The cushion is both bouncy and responsive. The traction is awesome, and it has all the support you need.
For $125 you get premium materials and modern tech. I enjoyed playing in these a lot! The only issues are the slightly mushy cushioning and the problematic containment on lateral cuts.
The KT4 uses the same fingerprint traction pattern used in the KT3 and it works incredibly well.
The KT4 has one of the best tractions available on the market. It grips insanely and performed amazingly.
The traction pattern bites super hard and stops on a dime. On dirty courts, it collects dust easily and it's not easy to wipe.
The foam cushioning used is very similar to Boost and is very bouncy/springy in the rear while the front offered solid court feel with impact protection.
The cushion is awesome. Bouncy in the forefoot and plenty of impact protection in the heel. It is one of the best cushion setups available.
The cushioning is super soft - almost too soft. Impact protection is crazy good but it feels a bit mushy and I didn't like the high offset of the heel.
The upper material looks similar to the Battleknit used in the Lebron 15 but offers more lockdown and is less stretchy.
This colorway (East Bay Times) specifically was a good performer since it had synthetic leather, but I was not a fan of the mesh uppers for performance.
The materials are very soft and feel super premium.
Extended outrigger, heel counter, and midfoot shank provide ample support.
The TPU counter on the lateral side of the shoe offers amazing lateral support and stability to help with side steps and quick stops when planting your foot.
There is a little bit of sliding on lateral cuts and the ankle support is pretty minimal.
The lockdown of the upper is surprisingly good.
I found my pair with the synthetic leather upper to have better lockdown than my mesh upper pair.
The knitted upper material started off a little snug but now it's almost too loose.
It should be ok for occasional outdoor use.
The rubber is pretty soft and pliable, I am not sure about outdoor use.
If you have wide feet, you should go true to size.
There is a little dead space in the toe box and the knitted upper is pretty soft and adapts to your feet.
I would suggest half a size down for regular footers.
I went down half a size because the knit stretches out with time.
The LeBron 16 will suit any play style or move — be it slashing, cutting, shooters, defense, rebounding.
I really, really like the Lebron 16. The price is expensive but justified by the amazing tech and ultra-premium feel.
The Lebron 16 is an upgrade in every aspect! They look better, they feel better, and they perform better!
The Lebron 16 is an outstanding performer!
Everything I didn't like about the Lebron 15 was fixed! Better traction, better stability, and containment. This is the best Lebron to come out in years!

The cushioning setup is super fun to play in, the traction worked on every court and the Battleknit 2.0 is super comfortable. The Lebron 16 is a very versatile shoe, but explosive and fast wing players will particularly love this hoops shoe.
Awesone impact protection, really good traction, but the court feel is minimal and the Lebron 16 is pretty heavy.
Cushioning and traction are awesome but the fit and support were a bit of a letdown for me.

My first Lebron shoes, bought them for outdoor use. First impression - horrific court feel, boots-like. High ride, gotta get used to it. Incredible cushioning setup for outdoor use - the impact protection is godly and the bounciness is enjoyable. Nice lateral stability. Gorgeous looking, premium feeling. Cons - excessive cushioning for indoor play (I'm >100kg). my right toenail became arch enemies with those shoes, I have to tape it heavily otherwise it gets black after one training (pressure)

This shoe is nuts. Initially very stiff, the cushioning breaks in after a while and feels like an air mattress beneath your feet. Supreme bounce without sacrificing mobility and court feel, this cushion is best utilised by larger, powerful humans like Bron himself. Traction is epic, nice thick grooves do the job at the highest level. Battleknit is super flexible and my foot feels like it can breath in it. The perfect shoe for a big, explosive athlete like the man this shoe was made for.

Pretty okay pair of shoes. I primarily use these for inside basketball, but they hold up well outside too. If i'm being honest, i expected more for the expensive price. The shoes really aren't anything special, and do not provide a very "premium" feel. Accounting for price or not, I'd choose Dame 5's over these any day of the week. For outside and

This review is for outdoor use only. Using these outdoors was great. They are some of the most comfortable shoes I've worn. The materials were phenomenal. The traction was good for the outdoors. Unfortunately, they did not last long. They lasted about 3-4 months before one of the air max things popped. For Lebrons, they weren't very heavy.

Overall, this shoe surprised me about how good it is. Traction bites hard, even on dusty courts. I have nothing to say about cushioning except for amazing, but its heavy. However, there's one thing I don't like in this shoe is support, I rolled a few times my ankle when I was running, but it rarely happens.
The Lebron 16 features gripping, thick traction that needs no wiping, and no breaking in.
Not amazing - but pretty damn nice. Dust doesn't seem to be a problem.
Super hard rubber and deep grooves work well, but don't expect a lot of squeaking or insane grip.
The traction on the Lebron 16 is really nice! Even on dusty courts, you will have to wipe only very occasionally.
The best traction of a Lebron since the X.
The Lebron 16 held up extremely well even on the worst courts.
The traction is really good!
The wavy herringbone traction pattern was super impressive.
The LeBron 16 has a stiffer overall setup that still provides serious impact protection but feels quicker and smoother from the jump.
The cushioning of the Lebron 16 is high up off-the-ground and provides insane impact protection and bounce. The responsiveness is okay, but the court feel is minimal.
The cushioning is a little more responsive and less bouncy than the cushioning of the Lebron 15. This setup works a lot better for guards like me.
Lower ride and not as bouncy as the Lebron 15. This cushioning is still made for bigger and heavier players and  I would have liked more responsiveness.
The high-off-the-ground Zoom cushioning provides the perfect balance of impact protection and responsiveness.
The cushioning isn't as crazy bouncy as it was in the predecessor. This time we get a more versatile and responsive setup.
The court feel isn't great I love the impact protection!
The Zoom Max cushioning is super comfortable and provides a ton of impact protection. The cushioning is pretty high off the ground which means you lose a little court feel.
It isn’t the most premium of materials, but it’s nicer than most and performs well.
The Battleknit 2.0 is pretty soft and pliable from the start.
Battleknit 2.0 feels a lot stronger and more durable than the Battleknit used in the Lebron 15.
Battleknit 2.0 is really, really nice. This version is thicker and stronger which fixes the containment issues of the Lebron 15.
I really like the use of the thicker and less stretchy Battleknit 2.0
The materials are a standout feature of this shoe.
The upper is a bit more rigid and supportive compared to the Lebron 15.
The materials are super comfortable, soft, and wrap around your feet very nicely.
Battleknit 2.0 is tighter and less stretchy which improves lateral containment. The wide and stable base, as well as the added outriggers, provide stability on lateral cuts.
The support is amazing! Materials don't stretch at all and the lateral stability problems of the Lebron 15 are a thing of the past.
The support and lockdown are much improved compared to the Lebron 15.
Zero heel slippage, no side-to-side movement, and the tiny outriggers improve lateral stability a lot!
Stability is drastically improved compared to the Lebron 15 by adding a tiny outrigger.
Lockdown is pretty good but the ankle support is only average.
The dead space and the fact that the cushioning is pretty high off the ground negatively impacted the stability for me.
After my fourth wear everything about the shoe just formed around my foot when laced tight and there is now no movement at all.
The Lebron 16 fits like a glove!
Nice and comfortable fit after a short break-in period.
The one-bootie upper is easy to put on thanks to the flexible tongue and the additional lower eyelets provide a lot of flexibility to get the perfect fit for your feet.
Í did have a little heel slip in the beginning that was fixed by using the lower eyelet and breaking in the midsole.
I went down half a size but the fit was still sloppy for me. I tried to adjust the lacing but couldn't get rid of the dead space in the toe box.
The fit is perfect for wide-footers, but I experienced a lot of dead space in the toe box and midfoot.
Thick and heavy rubber that should work well outdoors.
As a wide-footer, I didn't have any issues with the fit.
No dead-space at all for my fat feet.
I had to wear an additional pair of socks with my slightly narrow feet.
We went own half a size for a really snug and tight fit.
Runs true to size.
I went true to size but I feel narrow-footers can go down half a size.
They fit true to size.
The Adidas Pro Bounce Low is a great shoe that is absolutely perfect for me. Everything about this shoe is amazing and the cheap price point makes it even better!
The Adidas Pro Bounce Low is a great all-around shoe that should work especially well for guards.
Right now, this is by far my favorite shoe to hoop in. If you enjoy playing in low-tops then this is the perfect shoe for you!
The Pro Bounce Low is a very solid shoe that can be used for all positions.

Type of adidas shoes I love. Nothing spectacular at first sight but you respect them more every time you play. (I own a Mid version btw but they are almost same). Awesome traction. Good support, low-to-ground feeling. OUTRIGGERS. Bounce cushioning is sufficient for indoor play. Nice upper materials, nice lacing. Overall a masterpiece of sports engineering. I'd add a loop on the tongue, though, since it likes to move side to side. Live in my bag as replacement shoe for any wrong gym or situation.
Very dependable shoe with amazing traction and durability.
The bite of the traction pattern is really, really nice.
Traction is great on clean courts and after a short break-in period, the traction works on dusty courts too.
The traction pattern worked like a charm. The only downside is that it collects a lot of dust on dirty courts.
The spiral pattern provides solid traction from start to finish.
I think Adidas Bounce is one of the best cushioning setups on the market.
The Bounce cushioning is very responsive, low-to-the-court and provides a lot of court feel. Impact protection is still decent.
The Bounce cushioning is super low profile and very responsive. I might even prefer it over Boost cushioning.
Bounce cushioning is one of the most well-balanced rides from a foam currently available on the market.
I really enjoyed
The mesh upper with enforced forged fiber stitching is comfortable and very supportive.
The textile mesh construction which is backed by forged fibre is comfortable, durable and requires no break-in time.
ForgeFiber is a lightweight mesh with additional stitching that works great but feels a little cheap.
I didn't have any heel slippage, lateral containment is great and outriggers keep your feet from rolling.
After the break-in period, I didn't experience any heel slippage or lateral containment issues.
The support comes from the lateral outrigger, internal TPU heel counter, lockdown of the upper and works very well.
Good lockdown, torsional support from two TPU spring plates and a wide and flat outsole with two large outriggers provide great support.
I really enjoyed the fit of the Pro Bounce.
The lacing system really makes the shoe conform to your feet.
I had a little bit of dead space in the toe box but the lockdown was still solid.
Outdoor use should be okay.
Whether you have narrow or wide feet, don't worry about the sizing.
True to my Adidas size (which is half a size smaller than Nike)
Go true to size.
These are up there on the budget category. I would totally recommend the Jordan Jumpman Hustle, as they are one of the best performers of the year!
I think the Jordan Jumpman Hustle is a great performer, especially after you break-in the traction a little bit.
The Jordan Jumpman Hustle is super comfortable, very lightweight and the shoe won’t break the bank. Traction and cushioning are great but support could be better.
Overall, the Jordan Jumpman Hustle was a delight to play in.
Love the shoes. They have an amazing fit and great traction.
The mostly translucent full-length herringbone traction pattern is really nice.
The traction started off a little disappointing but got much better over time.
Simple herringbone traction works well but tends to clog up a little on dusty courts.
Traditional herringbone traction is used and sometimes it’s the simple things are what work best.
The cushioning is super low and very responsive with decent impact protection - I was impressed!
Provides a little bit of impact protection, bounce and a solid amount of court feel and responsiveness.
Forefoot Zoom Air and a Phylon midsole feel springy in the forefoot and comfortable in the heel.
The comfortable cushioning worked very well for me as a heavy-footed big guy.
The upper is thin, cozy, and feels premium.
I don't like the look of the synthetic shroud that covers the upper. The mesh material is nothing special, but performs well.
I love the look and feel of the materials on-foot.
While the material combination is nice, I do wish there was a little bit more strength behind the materials/build.
The lockdown and containment are fantastic but there is no real outrigger and the base could be a little wider.
No heel slippage, no side-to-side movement, and good containment.
Support is decent overall, but explosive lateral movements can be a bit problematic because of the stretchy upper material.
Support was good, not great, but good.
Really nice, snug fit with no dead space.
Overall, the fit of the one-bootie upper was really nice
