The Asia release model tested is built on a slightly wider last which worked well for my feet.
The rubber is thick and pretty hard, should be okay outdoors.
I am a slightly wide-footer and I did not have any problems.
I went true to size but the shoe felt a little bit long.
Personally, I would not recommend the KD11 for basketball because of the missing lateral support. Playing in these shoes had me scared about my ankles.
The KD 11 is a decent performer, but it just wasn't for me. I would recommend this shoe only to bigger pull-up shooters - there just isn't enough support for quicker players like me.
I was really disappointed because I expected more. The KD11 looks nice and is very comfortable but the performance aspects like support and traction just aren't as good as I had hoped.

If you want a sock-like shoe with great cushioning then you are going to love the KD11. Unfortunately, the missing support and lacking containment are issues I personally can't ignore in a performance basketball shoe.
Cushioning, materials, and traction are great. The only problem is the lack of support.
The Nike KD11 looks like a comfortable casual sneaker but doesn't work on a basketball court for me because of the lacking support and stability.
The KD11 is one of the most disappointing shoes I reviewed in a while. The fully knit build is just not supportive enough for a performance basketball shoe - use some leather Nike!

I am a lighter guard with wide feet. I wanted to give the KD line a try and I was disappointed. The heel tabs have left a scar on my ankles from the chafing they caused. The materials felt sturdy and tough, which is a plus for me. This shoe seemed to be a real hit or miss, with user experience dependent on how your ankle is shaped. Sadly, I have bigger ankles than the audience Nike designed these for, and I could never shake the weird feeling during use. They are durable as hell.
I really like this shoe. But the downfall of this shoe is the pull tab where it digs in my Achilles and it hurts a lot.
Outdoor players are lucky to explore this tbh.    :)
The translucent rubber offers great stopping power on clean courts, but on more dusty courts it was super inconsistent.
The traction of the KD 11 is good, even on a dusty court.
The traction is pretty inconsistent - works very well on clean courts but slides a lot on dusty courts.
Works fine on clean courts, needs some wiping on dirty courts.
The traction is fantastic and holds up even on mildly dusty courts.
The traction started off very nicely but seemed to fade a little after breaking it in.
The rubber frays easily and dust gets clogged in the narrow traction pattern instantly.
The combination of React and full-length Zoom is freaking amazing.

The nice and plush insole provides great step-in comfort.  The cushioning started off stiff, but after a while, I could feel the full-length Zoom that is similar to the cushioning of the Why Not Zero.1.
React's impact protection and Zoom Air's responsiveness is a crazy combination!
The React + Zoom cushioning feels great underfoot with a nice bounce and without any lag.
Combining React and Zoom gives you low-profile responsiveness, comfort, and a lot of bounciness.
The cushioning is very comfortable and provides a ton of impact protection. Unfortunately, it's also clunky, stiff and doesn't give you much court feel or responsiveness.
The combination of React and Zoom Air is money!
The implementation of the Flyknit upper could have been better.
The upper materials need a little to break in but feel very nice afterwards.
Overall, the materials are okay. The toe box and the heel counter are very sturdy, the mid-foot upper is soft and comfortable. I would have liked more padding on the inside of the tongue.
Feels nice and comfortable and premium but does nothing performance wise in my opinion.
The Flyknit upper is very light and feels great on foot.
The Flyknit is just too soft for a performance basketball.
Lockdown in the heel was fine but I felt my foot slipping off the footbed a lot. This feels like a very dangerous shoe to play in if you do a lot of lateral cuts.
I was sliding all over the place in this shoe because the upper material is not strong enough to provide the necessary lockdown. If you rely on cuts and crossovers, then this shoe is not for you.
The support was a downer for me as the mid-foot panel is too stretchy for my liking. I was always afraid of ankle sprains because my feet were rolling over on hard lateral cuts.
The upper is super stretchy and doesn't provide a lot of containment. Stability is fine even if there is basically no heel counter.
There is barely any support in this shoe. If you do a lateral cut or a step back your foot almost falls out of the shoe - not comfortable!!
The horrible heel lockdown and constant front-to-back movement inside the shoe didn't inspire confidence for hard cuts and crossovers.
Because of the stretchy and sloppy materials I never felt safe playing in these shoes.
The fit of the one-bootie upper is really nice after a short break-in period.
There is a good amount of heel slip to start but it gets a lot better after the break-in period.
The overall fit was pretty good but not outstanding.
I don't like the sock-construction often used in modern basketball shoes, but the harness-like system hidden under the Flyknit upper improved the comfort a little bit for me.
Never once did I feel securely locked into the shoe.
I wouldn't recommend this shoe outdoors because of the soft rubber.
Would I take them outdoors? Probably not.
Runs narrow like we are used to from KD shoes.
Slightly narrow like all Durant's shoes.
Long and narrow like every KD shoe ever.
Going down half a size should be the right choice except for the widest-footers.
Fits just like the KD9 or KD10. I went true to size and this worked perfectly for me.
Good traction, good cushioning and the support and lockdown are on point. The materials may look cheap but they perform well.  Overall, a very solid hoops shoe!
The latest Nike Kobe A.D. isn't spectacular, but it is an easy recommendation for players whose priorities lean towards light, minimal, and low shoes.
It's a great performing shoe, but for a Kobe signature model, the look and in-hand feel of the materials are disappointing.
I like everything about this shoe! I just wished they would have taken the cushion from the Kobe AD NXT 360, because then it would have been my shoe of the year!
It doesn't have the latest and greatest tech but this is definitely one of the more fun shoes I played in this year.
The Kobe AD Exodus isn't the best Kobe ever, but it does almost everything well on-court and is smooth on foot. Works especially well for quicker "Kyrie-like" guards.

I like the Nike Kobe AD Exodus but I don’t love it. The Exodus is lightweight, low profile, and provides aggressive traction — it’s a shoe built for a fast-paced player that gets up and down the court.
I am having fun in the Kobe AD, but the traction is problematic.
Tech-wise it's not great but performance is solid and it looks good. Overall, we are a little underwhelmed though and the Kobe AD Exodus probably won't make it into our rotation.

As my first-ever pair of Kobes, these would fit the description of an "entry-level sneaker". Traction was good, cushion was average as this is a shoe meant most for guard and support was average. Materials could've been better and the fit was a little strange for me at first, but overall a solid performer nonetheless.

One of my favorite shoes. Amazing court feel, responsiveness, and bounce. My one downfall would be the limited customizable fit without a tongue, it's more of a slip on, luckily they fit my foot pretty great.
I really like these shoes. They have lasted through me and my brother for five years. Their traction is very good for what is left on them and I wish I had a new par.
The traction is a strong suit of the Kobe AD Exodus and works especially well on clean courts.
The translucent rubber provides outstanding traction and required very little wiping.
Overall, the traction was pretty good but I did have some slip-ups on a very dusty court. After a quick wipe, you are ready to go again.
The Kobe AD Exodus picks up a lot of dust, but it didn't affect performance at all.
Looks similar as the NXT360 but performs better for me. Feels a little tackier and picks up little dust.
Traction works well on clean courts but on dusty courts, you have to wipe every 4-5 possessions.
I've had nothing but a positive experience with the traction.
I was slipping all over the place.
It started off really bad but got better with time. The Kobe AD Exodus picks up a lot of dust and is hard to wipe.
The cushioning is responsive, bouncy and springy - I like it!

The Phylon forefoot lacks the dynamic response of Air Zoom but provides excellent court feel and a very speedy feel which works perfectly for fast guards. The Air Zoom in the heel provides decent impact protection.
The forefoot is low-to-the-ground and responsive with a lot of court feel. The Zoom unit in the heel provides bounciness and impact protection.
The stiff Phylon in the forefoot did tire my feet after a while of playing.
The Zoom Air units in Phylon carrier feels plush, absorbing and springy enough. I think most players will like this setup - I sure did.
Huge 14mm Zoom Air unit in the heel and basic injected Phylon in the forefoot. Not bad, but I would prefer full-length Zoom cushioning.
At $140 I expect better forefoot cushioning than injected Phylon. The heel Zoom Air unit is nice.
I liked the bouncier cushioning setup of the Exodus compared to other current Kobe models. I felt very explosive and responsive.
The cushioning in the heel feels great. The forefoot has very little cushioning but is therefore very responsive. Overall, the shoe felt high-off-the-ground.
The materials are not premium but feel good, fit good and get the job done.
The materials used in the Exodus are not up to par with other Kobe models like the AD NXT 360. On-court performance of the materials is solid.
The synthetic felt-like upper materials looks a little cheap but offered great containment and performance.
The materials feel kinda cheap but work fine.
I’ve seen better, but the materials work.
The performance wasn't hindered by the materials, but the synthetic felt-like suede upper feels and looks cheap.
The materials feel a little cheap but perform well.
The materials don't feel premium on-hand or on-feet but perform well.
The sculpted collar padding and external heel counter provide the excellent stability we know from the Kobe line.
No heel slippage, no slipping on the footbed and no lateral instability.
Not once did I feel insecure in these shoes! No lateral movement, great lockdown, and stable base.
The support was fine for a Low-cut. Stability is great in the forefoot and just a little unstable and squishy in the heel.
Standard heel counter and raised midsole in the heel do an okay job. The missing lateral outrigger and midfoot shank didn't negatively impact stability.
The outsole is flat and the forefoot section is slightly wider to provide stability. Your foot sits within the midsole which acts as a natural outrigger - a setup I love.
The lockdown in the forefoot is absolutely fantastic, the midfoot and heel felt a little slippery out-of-the-box.

Feels light and comfortable.
I am not a fan of the sock-like construction and its lack of adjustability. But the Kobe AD Exodus provides above average fit considering the limitations of this construction.
Feels like it hugs my feet except for the flimsy and soft toebox.
The lacing system is fire!
The fit is great with no heel slip or other movement inside the shoes.
Lockdown is complete and total.

No outdoor use for these!
These felt perfectly fine for me as a wide-footer.

Runs true to size.

For a retail price of $100, this is an outstanding shoe.
If the Curry 3 Zero2 came with a heel counter it would be the perfect guard shoe.
The Steph Curry 3 Zero2 does almost everything exceptionally well with traction, fit and stability being the very high highlights.

The shoes traction was very good but it's cushionimg was hard and it was very uncomfortable to wear If u want this show I suggest going up half a size or a size it also hurts your feet when u play and u risk injury overall I don't recommend
Very solid shoe doesn’t really shine in one area but its overall good. Dust pickup wasn’t an issue had a fun time in this shoe.
I had no problems at all with this traction.

This traction pattern is great and works well on all surfaces.

This is one of my top 5 performance basketball shoes of 2018 so far!
Okay overall, but nothing great aside from traction, stability, and containment.

my first ever kyrie shoe and I've loved it for volleyball. The front-loaded zoom unit allows for explosive jumping and quick movements from side to side. Would recommend these shoes to anyone with narrow feet, and want a durable explosive feeling shoe.

It may be an opinion clouded in sentiment, but there is no denying it: the Protro is a great, great, great performer.
I miss shoes that are built like this. Nike reduced a bit of bulk from the original and created a shoe that I didn't want to take off again.

The Kobe 1 Protro feels and plays like the OG which is a good thing! From traction to containment and balanced cushioning - it does everything right and gets a first-team rating from me!

Leather upper very supportive but unbreathable. Too heavy and bulky shoe for shifty guards. But traction, air zoom cushioning, materials quality, support patterns is AMAZING. Slightly long shoe btw.
It’s pretty bulky, the cushion is stiff and the traction is nice but not top notch. Is really a beautiful shoe, but i wouldn’t consider it a great performer.
Just my kinda shoes, but it's heavy and not very breathable due to the material use, but loves it in terms of traction, cushion and kobe.

Nike Zoom Ari cushioning like it was originally designed to be: low, fast, speedy and responsive.

Super-nice, old-school, real leather.

The leather is very soft and feels great on foot.
Wide base, large outrigger, lateral support from foam teeth on the lateral side of the midsole and the sturdy leather provide all the support you need.

Hugs my feet nicely and the leather feels comfortable after breaking it in.
No heel slip. No movement side to side. Well done Nike!
Even though I spent a ton of time trying to lace the Kobe 1 Proto as tight as possible, I didn't feel locked-in because the leather didn't conform to my feet.
I felt the fit was bulky and cumbersome.
Outdoor use should be good because of the hard and thick rubber.
Slightly narrow in the forefoot but loosens up over time.
The Kobe 1 Proto runs wide.
Runs true to size.
I went down half a size and they fit me just fine.
Runs true to size.
Overall, the Kobe NXT 360 is the best Kobe shoe since the Kobe 9, in my opinion.
There is no other shoe I want to play in as much as these. Even though the traction of the translucent rubber is not the best this still might be the best basketball shoe we ever played in.
The Kobe AD NXT 360 is a great performer and looks amazing!
This is officially PureKicks best-rated shoe so far!

The traction is subpar, the 360 Flyknit concept is cool but nothing spectacular and the price is too expensive for what you get.

The traction wasn’t bad, but it wasn’t the best either. Works well on clean courts but dusty courts are problematic.

The traction is phenomenal even on dustier courts!
You don't have to worry about slipping or sliding at all.
Traction on the Kobe NXT 360 started out phenomenally but has already lost some of its grip after 4 weeks of use.
The traction doesn't grip the floor very well even after breaking them in.

Traction was a bit disappointing as It didn’t have the bite I was expecting on clean floors and picked up a decent amount of dust.
The comfort is there, the impact protection is there, the court feel is there — the stuff is just amazing.
The best cushioning setup we have ever experienced. Nike just nailed it!
This is one of my favorite cushioning setups and comes really close to full-length Zoom.
The mixture of Nike React and Lunarlon feels absolutely incredible.
The mixed React and Lunarlon drop-in midsole provides a fluid ride with a lot of court-feel in the front and impact protection in the rear.
Nike Lunarlon combined with React cushioning is solid but I like more responsive cushioning like Nike Zoom Air.
Very low to the ground, responsive and a ton of court feel. If you need a lot of impact protection - this is not for you.
If you want low to the ground yet comfortable and balanced cushioning, then this is your set up.
I'm almost speechless because the materials are so nice!
The upper is incredibly minimal, doesn't stretch and provides very good ventilation.
The pure 360 Flyknit in the rear feels amazing, the front is TPU reinforced to provide more lockdown and durability.  Being able to see through the upper is really cool and unique.
The materials are probably the most comfortable I ever experienced in a basketball shoe.
360-degrees of Flyknit was hyped up quite a bit. It performs well, but it wasn’t anything spectacular.
The extremely lightweight and flexible 360 Flyknit material is truly cutting edge and feels like an extension of your feet.
TPU reinforced Flyknit is very breathable and comfortable.
The support comes mainly drom the drop-in midsole and is fantastic.
No heel slippage, great containment, and lateral support.
Zero heel slippage, no side-to-side movement. I just would have wished to get a lateral outrigger.
The support is very, very good considering the minimal build of the upper.
For  $200 I would have liked a few more support features like an external outrigger or a mid-foot carbon fiber plate.
The support was surprisingly good considering the type of construction.
Stability is not an issue with the Kobe AD NXT 360!
Support is fine for a low top with excellent heel fit and a decent heel counter. However, the rounded outsole with no outrigger is just asking me for an ankle sprain.
Great lockdown and very good ventilation.
This is the best fitting shoe I have ever worn!
Nice 1:1 fit, no complaints at all!
The fit of this shoe is very good.
Lockdown was surprisingly good, and if you get the right size, then this shoe feels like an extension of your foot!
The fit is awesome - I had a second skin experience!
Great heel lockdown, no dead space in the toe box, no side-to-side movement and the thin upper feels like a second skin. The fit is the highlight of the 360 -  no doubt!
Outdoor use is not recommended.
The rubber is pretty soft and the pattern is too narrow for outdoor use.
I would definitely not take these outdoors.
The width is pretty narrow.
I have slightly wide feet but the Kobe AD NXT 360 didn't bother me in my true size.
The shoe will conform to the shape of your feet and worked perfectly fine for my wide feet.
They run long, go down half a size!
Go true to size, even if you have slightly wide feet.
True-to-size fit me perfectly well.
I went true to size with the 360 and it has a tiny bit of extra length in the toe but not enough to size down half a size.
The Lebron Soldier 12 is 100% worth its price! It's just nice to play in a shoe with gnarly traction like this!
If you want a shoe that does everything very well, this is your shoe.
The traction was surprisingly fantastic! The fit was brillitant, the support was good, if only the materials would have been better!

The traction is absolutely amazing, even on dusty courts!
The pliable rubber with a simple blade pattern just works on every surface with minimal wiping.
The traction really bit the floor even on dusty courts!
Bottom-loaded heel and forefoot Zoom in a firm Phylon midsole. Impact protection is decent, courtfeel is not great as you feel pretty high up.
Overall, I’m happy with how the Soldier XII feels underfoot.
With forefoot Zoom and heel Zoom you are taken care off!
Neoprene-like material around the midfoot and canvas / leather depending on the colorway on the forefoot. It's not as premium as the Battleknit on the Lebron 15, but still really nice!
The synthetic leather feels very premium and the knit looks very similar to Battleknit.
The straps weren't holding up - we had to restrap all the time which was pretty annoying. Also the ventilation was pretty bad.
The straps of the Lebron 12 give you a very nice lockdown, no heel slippage or lateral movement.
Support is average with a pretty flexible sock like upper.
Heel counter, outrigger, and nice lockdown are there. Feels like a low top, but the support is good.
The fit is very good overall with the Soldier XII without any heel slip or wide to side movement and no dead space in the forefoot at all.
Fits like an glove and requires minimal break-in.
You could get away with it, if you really want to.
Hard rubber, deep grooves - what more do you want?
True to size.
Go true to size.
This is by far the cheapest signature model on the market but it's still a very good performer. We enjoyed it a lot!
Considering that the Kyrie Flytrap is a budget model it gets the job done, but it's nothing spectacular. Save some extra money and get the Kyrie 4.
Not a bad shoe for $80, but I would opt for discounted Kyrie 4s — unless you happen to have a wide foot.
I can't recommend the Kyrie Flytrap from a performance standpoint. The Flytrap feels so cheap that it doesn’t even feel like it was made by Nike.
Is it worth your $80 bucks? I don’t think so.
If you are a looking cheap outdoor shoe, flytrap series good option for you. Good for shifty guards who dont need cushion. But materials and fit line is so bad.
Good shoe to play in especially outdoors. It's mainly for guards, it focuses on response than impact protection
Great for wide footers and this is the only shoe that the traction got worse each time i played in it.

Works well on well-maintained courts, but I had problems on old and dusty courts.

The basic materials feel light and comfortable and get the job done.

The Lebron 15 Low is a vast improvement over last year's Lows. It's a little more guard-oriented with less cushioning and better stability and traction during lateral cuts. It also works well for lighter players that didn't like the bulky High-top version of the Lebron 15.
I am not a big fan of the Lebron 15 Low. Expensive, heavier than most Lows and the high ride won't work for quick guards who rely on lateral cuts.

Lower ride, very responsive but less springy and not as much impact protection as the High.

The PG 2 is a really fun shoe to play because it enhanced nearly every feature found on the PG 1.
The PG2 has slightly improved in every aspect: better cushioning, nicer materials, more comfortable fit and slightly improved traction make them a contender for best shoe of 2018.
The Nike PG 2 is a well-rounded shoe and great for people all shapes and sizes. I’d say its definitely an upgrade from the PG 1.
The PG2 is honestly the best all-around shoe that Nike has on the market right now (especially at $110).
The PG2 performs well across all aspects and comes at an extremely fair price.
The Nike PG2 is a slight improvement over the PG1 and in the competition for the best bang-for-the-buck basketball shoe on the market.

Comfortable PrimeKnit in the collar, the rest of the upper is made from a dual-layer mesh that looks and feels like a woven material. Overall, the materials are soft, flexible and deliver an old-school style with some new-school flavor.

The full-length zoom setup is worth the $125 alone. A great big-man shoe as the cushion is amazing!

What a fantastic shoe this is. I’m not a fan of Russell Westbrook, but man, do I love playing in his shoe.

To me, this will be one of the top performance sneakers of 2018. Full-length zoom at $125 - you can't beat that!

very heavy, and not breathable. otherwise super enjoyable shoe

At $120, the Kyrie 4 is an absolute steal! This is a very well constructed shoe and an absolute beast on the court. Probably my favorite shoe to play in right now!

Overall, the Nike Kyrie 4 is Nike’s best performer this year. There’s just enough cushion for most, solid traction, fantastic fit and adequate support — and all of comes at a “team” friendly price point of $120.
The Kyrie 4 is the best Kyrie to date. This shoe has everything and is Nike’s best all-around hooping kick right now.
This is the best Kyrie signature shoe ever. The traction is amazing and the cushion and materials are vastly improved.
The Kyrie 4 is one of Nike’s best-performing signature shoes that works well at all positions.

The Kyrie 4 is a phenomenal addition to the Kyrie line. It comes with improved cushioning and materials, great fit and support. The traction is a little disappointing, but for $120 these are a great pickup!
Definitely the best shoe in the Kyrie signature line so far. Perfect for quick guards who don't rely a lot on impact protection.
I had a lot of fun in the Kyrie 4! I give them a B+ - it's not quite elite, but almost there. However, at a $120 price these offer great value!

All in all, the Kyrie 4 is a solid shoe that does everything fairly well, while doing nothing outstanding or really poorly. Cushioning has improved, the traction is decent overall and I really liked the comfort of the plush interior.
Overall, I am satisfied with the Kyrie 4. Minimal break-in time, great traction and a fair price. The Kyrie 4 gets the job done!

The Nike Kyrie 4 is a nice shoe for guards. It is a reliable low to the ground shoe. The traction was pretty good on a clean court, but it slipped a little on dust. The traction was still pretty good tho, so you should be fine. The cushion isn’t too bad, but it’s nothing special either. It is responsive and has amazing court feel. The support was pretty good, and the rounded outsole helped with stability, so that you dont roll your ankle easily. The upper wasn’t the best, but it was pretty good!

I played in a single pair of Kyrie 4s all through high school. The materials feel amazing and the shoes are still holding to this day, almost 2 years removed from those days. I tie my laces extremely tight, and when other shoes would show wear by stretching and popping, the Kyries would stand strong. They’re solid when you need them to be and versatile otherwise. My only complaint is that any amount of dust on the traction surface would lead to lots of slipping. They do have a roomy toebox.

This is one of the first good shoes i played with. The traction was decent but sometimes i would slip some. Cushion is great and much better than previous kyrie models. The stability was amazing and i didn't have any problems with heel slip or containment. The ventilation is not great though as the shoe can get pretty hit for me, although i don't mind it much. Overall i think this is great for shifty players but it also has good stability for big men, aesthetically this is my favorite model.

The Kyrie 4 is pretty similar to the Kyrie 3, but a WHOLE lot comfier! I absolutely LOVED the Cushlon midsole, it provided a perfect amount of both cushion and response! The traction is a bit of a downgrade from the 3, but still pretty dang good for me. Overall I highly recommended this shoe for all positions!
One of my favorite juries I’ve had. Played some of my best ball in them. Love the kyrie ones and these the most. Might get another pair sometime my other ones are beat after a year or two in them

Support on the Kyrie 4 was something I had no issues with.
I felt very secure.

The Kyrie series has always been solid from a fit standpoint.
The fit is super nice and comfortable.

Go true to size.

The Way of Wade 6 is a solid performer, and I enjoy this shoe a lot. I find myself going to this sneaker just about much as I go to my Dame 4s.

The Curry 4 feels super-duper responsive. As one of the lightest shoes on the market, it provides great traction, tight fit, and low-to-the-ground feeling which makes it the perfect shoe for quick guards.
The Curry 4 is a great shoe for guards that rely on quick, responsive movements. I really liked everything about it except the very minimal impact protection.
The Curry 4 is a great shoe for quick, ball-handling point guards who need speed with no lag.
The Under Armour Curry 4 is a fantastic shoe for anyone looking for court feel. For the people who want impact protection I’d say stay clear from the Curry 4.
The Curry 4 feels like it should have come after the Curry 2. It provides a better fit, greater stability, and more control.

This is the best Curry signature shoe so far. Great traction, good cushioning and support - perfect for quick guards.

The Under Armour Curry 4 is a great shoe for guards! It is a fast and responsive shoe, and it is very light. The traction was amazing on clean courts, and it was pretty good on dust as well. The shoe lacks cushioning, but if you want a responsive shoe with amazing court feel, this shoe is for you! The support was pretty good because of the upper, and it locks you in so your foot doesn’t move off the footbed. The upper is also pretty good, it is thin and breathable, but it takes time to break in.
10/10 amazing such a good shoe I had no problems. Overall amazing shoe

The Anta KT3 is a great shoe. Between the Dame 4, Curry 4 and KT3 I have one hell of a lineup to choose from on any given night.

The LeBron 15 is one of the best LeBron shoes ever. Materials, fit, and cushion are the definite highlights of the shoe.

I think this is one of the best Lebrons ever. Material usage is great, cushioning is great, support is great -  basically, everthing is really nice! But keep in mind that this shoe is made for big and heavy players, and won't work as well for smaller guards.

The Lebron 15 is the best Lebron of all time. This shoe ticks all the boxes, the only slight downside was the traction.

My favorite Lebron ever - I really enjoyed playing in the Lebron 15. The cushioning is insane, the materials are as premium as it gets, unfortunately, the price is too.

As a small guard, I didn't love the high-off-the-ground feeling and the laggy cushioning. However, if you are a bigger, heavier and powerful player than you will love the Lebron 15.

The LeBron 15 overall was pretty good. It had good traction, very comfortable cushion, nice feeling materials, and snug fit. The support on the other hand wasn't that nice considering the movement in the footbed, and the durability wasn't that good either since I ran through my outsole in about a week and half. But for the most part, it was solid.

The shoe is amazing on court, and has great support and cushion. I rarely roll my ankle or get ankle injuries with these shoes. The main problem is the side to side movements and traction on outdoor surfaces.
Great shoes with one con in the sole being too tight which had me rolling my ankle in random occasions while running.

Best. Zoom. Ever.

The Air Jordan 32 is a huge step in the right direction. Everything feels refined. If Jordan Brand can keep the stability but increase the flexibility then it will have perfected the Flight Speed setup. I think people are going to like this one.
The Air Jordan XXXII is a banger for real. This shoe has everything you need: good traction, good cushion, excellent materials, and amazing support.

This is hands down the best on-court Air Jordan Model to date, as it should be. Every feature fits the mold to near perfection. Jordan Brand took a huge step in the right direction across all performance aspects.
The AJ XXXII is a great shoe that should satisfy everyone except the minimalist hoop crowd that love shoes like the Kobe 8, Mamba Mentality, Instinct etc
Across the spectrum, this shoe performs very well and should work for all types of players. Pretty pricey, but worth every penny!

The Air Jordan 32 is a great performer and I was a little sad when I had to put these aside to test other performance shoes. The only two downsides are the long break-in period and the hefty price tag.

Despite sky-high expectations, the Air Jordan 32 mostly delivers. I liked the more minimal collar and feel of the 31s cushioning better, but thought the 32 offered far superior traction and a smoother transition.
I think this is a great shoe for in-between players who are looking for a good mix of comfortable cushioning and responsiveness.

I think Jordan brand did a great job with the XXXII. This has taken over the Nike PG1 as my go-to basketball shoes.  Traction, cushioning and lockdown are all great - what else do you need in a performance sneaker?
Pros: Great Traction, Cushioning provides a good balance between impact protection and res
Overall, I would describe the Air Jordan 32 as a responsive shoe with ultimate support. Great for big guys, but unfortunately, the traction was pretty disappointing.
Nice shoes with premium materials and nice cushioning. I was a bit disappointed by the traction and the lateral containment. At a steep $185 I wouldn't recommend these.

You could climb a wall in these shoes. They will grip to anything, no matter how much dust is on the surface. I played competitively for 3 years in a pair of these shoes. I liked to tie my laces tight, and the loops on the upper portion of the shoe are barely separating at this point. All good things come to an end, and I was sad to retire these shoes due to my worries over the durability of the loops. Everything else about the Jordan 32 is exemplary!
Not only did they grip the court, but it gripped really well.
Traction on the Air Jordan XXXII was straight up beast mode compared to the 31.
No matter hard the cuts I made, the Air Jordan 32 traction pattern played to all my needs.
Great traction especially on clean floors but not in the top tier across the spectrum of conditions.
The traction has an amazing bite and squeaks like nothing else.
The overall experience was pretty consistent but not perfect. You will need to wipe often on dusty courts.
The 32’s grip is as good as any I can remember an Air Jordan having.
The traction can be hit or miss.
The traction is really good. Inside or outside, we didn't have any problems.
The traction is probably the best aspect of the shoe. Even on dusty courts, you will need to wipe only very little.
The traction didn't feel great and took a lot of wiping. If you are a defender who likes to slip and slide - this is the shoe for you!
Not as bad as the Jordan 31, but not as good as the D Rose 8 or Kyrie 3 either.
Heel and forefoot segmented Zoom Air returns and for me, this setup feels more balanced than unlocked setups in the past.

Phylon carrier with unlocked Zoom in the front and regular Zoom in the heel. I wish more shoes would use this type of setup.
Very long break-in period, but after that, you get amazing energy return and high-level responsiveness. Probably the most versatile cushioning setup out there today.

Low to the ground feeling, bouncy but still responsive with good impact protection. I absolutely love it.

No heel slippage, no side-to-side movement, and my ankle felt really secure.
No thrills, no gimmicks - the support does a great job without doing anything special.
The molded collar, along with the ribbed external heel counter, give rock-solid stability. Combined with the forefoot outrigger, the shoe feels safe and secure.
Lockdown is excellent, lacing setup is a little bit tricky. Firm cushioning also helps with feeling very stable and secure.
Ankle support is very good but feels a little restrictive and bulky.
The support is fantastic, maybe even too much for smaller and quicker players. Great for big guys!
The Flyknit upper stretches a little too much for me. Ankle support is decent and lockdown is good.
The shoe just felt like it was made for my foot, something I really enjoy.
My foot did not move in this shoe no matter what I did.
The materials are comfortable and nicely conform to my foot.
No heel slip or movement side to side, just a tighter and more refined fit than the XXXI. Great job JB!
After the material breaks in the one-bootie upper gives you a great 1:1 fit.

The shoe fits very snug and I felt a little bit of pressure in the heel. After time went on the felt better.
Nice and plush feeling around your feet.
After breaking them in they are very comfortable. Materials fit really nicely to your feet, no unnecessary dead space at all.
Outdoor traction was good.
A solid rubber version should do the trick outdoors.
The rubber is super hard and thick, so outdoor use should be good.
The shoe feels slightly narrow.
They fit really snug and there is no dead space at all.
These run pretty narrow.
They are a tad long but I only had a little more than a finger width at the toe box which is my preference.
Runs a tad bit long.
Very snug, but I wouldn't recommend sizing up.
Maybe you want to go down half a size.
The Dame line continues to be the best signature you can get for your money. Bang for your buck like no other.
This is a really good performance basketball shoe - probably one of the best basketball shoes of 2017! Especially at the low list price of $115.
I was having so much fun in this kick I didn’t want to stop. If there was a category for “fun to play in” I would rate the Dame 4 Hall of Fame!
With good cushioning, good fit, and good materials, the Dame 4 is good at everything. As an overall package, this is one of the most complete and fun shoes to play in that you will ever find.
Decent cushion, good fit, good materials — the shoe is good for everything on the court and gives you a great overall package.
I loved playing in these. Perfect for guards who want to be low to the ground and are looking for a very responsive shoe.
The Dame 4 is the perfect shoe for quick guards and offers amazing performance at a very affordable price.

I really really really enjoy playing in this shoe but only on clean or slightly dusty floors. But the fact that I would even consider playing in these despite the meh traction speaks volumes about how fun this shoe is overall.
The Dame 4 is an underrated shoe that works very well for quick guards.
This is probably the best performing shoe to hoop in right now! This shoe is really smooth and I come back to it all the time.
Traction, cushion, fit were all great, and the support system is all I need. This is one of the best-value sneakers I have ever worn!

Best shoe I’ve played in. Only the Kyrie 6 were close to match it. It’s perfect for a quick and responsive point guard. You feel very low to the ground while you have very decent impact protection. I loved it. It may take some time to break in the traction, not too long; once it goes, it’s an amazing performer.
Was not a top tier performer to be fair and I honestly didn't like playing in it.Also the fit was the worst one I have experienced yet.The only positive think is the cushion.
The traction pattern worked and it worked really well.
Takes a really long time to break in. The traction is not as good as the Dame 2 or 3, but still really solid.
As weird as this outsole may look, the performance is insane.
The Dame 4 doesn’t feel aggressive in stops, but it never slipped out or slid while playing, which makes me a happy player.
This traction was as spot on as any other shoe I’ve played in this year.
The traction started off really bad but got a lot better after breaking in. Overall, the traction is solid, but you will need to wipe a lot on dusty courts.
On clean courts, the bite of the traction pattern is amazing. On dusty courts, it still held up pretty well.
After the break-in period, the traction isn't bad but it definitely isn’t middle top to top tier either.
I play on one of the dustiest courts of London and this traction did a fantastic job.
The traction is a bit inconsistent and collects dust very fast. In clean gyms, it works very well.
These gripped the floor very well for me!
Very low to the ground,  but the "Bounce" cushioning doesn't make you feel like you’re playing in a super firm cushion.
Man, do I love the cushioning in these. The perfect combination of comfort, responsiveness, court feel and impact protection.
This setup is one of the best low profile setups I have ever experienced. You can really feel the court underneath your foot.
Normally, I like a more cushioned feel but the Dame 4 felt so fast and fun that losing a little cushioning was outweighed.
Cushion works well for those who look for a low ride and immediate responsiveness.
Full-length bounce cushioning is really nice. Probably one of the lowest basketball shoes ever with a very good court feel. Impact protection is still good, especially in the heel.
Low-to-the-ground, very responsive and decent impact protection. The "Bounce" cushioning does a great job.
Full-length Bounce is back again and I have zero complaints.
The full-length Bounce cushioning is low to the ground, soft and responsive - just what you want as a quick guard.
I really like the Bounce cushioning.
The Bounce cushioning is more on the responsive side which works well for explosive players.
Nice mesh that allows for much better airflow than the Dame 3 did.
Soft and comfy - I really like the materials.
Anything I did the materials were right there with me. No pinching, binding, nothing — just nicely ventilated mesh.
The upper is thick but not stiff and provides a combination of flex and padding that immediately forms to your foot and feels like an extension of your foot.
For a “budget model” to provide materials of this caliber is amazing.
Materials are super nice and comfortable. The materials actually feel very premium - especially for the affordable price,
After the break-in period the materials feel really nice.
Materials aren’t high end in name, but feel and look premiumish.
The materials feel nice but look dirty very quickly.
The materials are soft and comfortable, durability might be a problem.
Fairly flat and stable base, outrigger, internal heel counter, midfoot torsional shank, and a wonderful 1-to-1 fit provide you with excellent support.
I had problems with the lacing system which made my foot move around a little inside the shoes. Otherwise, support is good.
If the fit is right, then the support is outstanding.
Overall, it isn’t restrictive, but definitely stable and supportive.

I had problems with slight heel slippage. Otherwise, the materials are strong and durable and provide excellent support for such a low shoe.
Gone are the problems I had with heel slippage in the Dame 3. Overall, I had no problems at all with support.

Internal heel counter, cable lacing system, and lateral outrigger provide good support. You need to tie the shoe really tightly to avoid heel slippage.
This shoe is more supportive than I expected.
The support systems are minimal but get the job done!
The entire shoe fit me perfectly 1-to-1 and felt like they were made for me.
Lockdown is crazy. The compression collar holds you in place and the lacing system is fire.
The fit is so tight - the lacing system is almost not even needed.
The shoe wraps around your foot seamlessly and acts like an extension of your body.
Snug as a bug.
A very nicely fitting shoe.
No heel slip, no lace pressure, no deadspace and no side to side movement
The fit was perfectly fine.
Initially, it was hard to put this shoe on, but now my feet are slipping right in.
Outdoor use is not recommended. Traction pattern is shallow, and rubber is on the softer side.
I don't recommend these to play outdoors.
These run pretty narrow.
For wide feet, I would stick with the regular size.
I went half a size down, to my regular Adidas size.
Go down half a size from what you are wearing in Nike's or Under Armours.
Runs slightly large.
I got mine true to size.
The Air Jordan 32 is a huge step in the right direction.
I think this shoe is worth every penny and I like the low-top version better than the regular mid. The Air Jordan 32 Low offers slightly better traction and more freedom of movement.
You get amazing cushioning, and premium materials. Unfortunately, the traction is a real dust collector. Decent performer, but probably not worth the hefty price tag
I really enjoyed playing in these! The Air Jordan 32 Low is super comfortable and performs very well.
The Lows seem to uses better rubber overall.
The traction is a huge improvement over the Air Jordan 31. I had no slipping issues at all, even on dusty courts. The Lows seem to have a slightly better traction than the Mids.
The traction is better than the 31, but it's still not amazing. This traction pattern is a real dust collector.
Performs very well on clean courts but you need to wipe a lot on dusty courts.
For me, this setup feels more balanced than unlocked setups in the past.

Cushion is very responsive but the heel-to-toe transition is a little clunky.
I absolutely love the materials on the Air Jordan 32.
The tightly woven knit is very durable and feels very premium.
This is probably the best Flyknit I ever felt in a basketball sneaker.
The materials feel super premium and comfortable.
There is an internal heel counter, as well as the visible external piece — both do their job well.
I like the feeling of a low-top and don't miss the added ankle support of the mid version. No heel slippage - no side-to-side movement.

Overall support performs well, but on aggressive crossovers my feet came out of the footbed a little bit.
The shoe just felt like it was made for my foot, something I really enjoy.
The one-bootie-upper has a nice 1:1 fit.
Tight and comfortable fit.
Outdoors, you will be fine.
I played outdoors in these a few times and had no problems at all.

The width is regular.

Fits a little bit longer.

The performance of the D Rose 8 is stellar. Feels like a lighter, streamlined and more minimal D Rose 7. I love these shoes and put them on the top of my list of Adidas performance sneakers.
By combining great traction, awesome cushioning, and serious fit, the Rose 8 is built for every player.

For $140 this is a really good shoe. It brings everything you want: impact protection, responsiveness, ventilation, support and really good traction. If you like supportive high-tops, then this is the perfect shoe for you!
The Adidas D Rose 8 is a very solid shoe. Traction is my main gripe with the Rose 8, but everything from the midsole up worked really well.

Since the D Rose 5, we’ve gotten great cushioning, traction, support and stability, and a reliable fit year over year and the D Rose 8 is no different. Materials aren’t always the best but that’s always been a non-issue for me.
No distractions! This is a traditional basketball shoe and a great overall performer. This shoe worked very well for my style of game!

everything was good especially the cushioning and traction . only problem i had was the laces were too short and hard to tie it properly . also the top front materials don't really last if you played frequently in it.
Good shoe overall. Rather short so I had to take it a size and a half above. Outdoor it is quite durable but the traction and the cushion are average.
The new "zipper" traction is really nice. The stopping power is amazing.
The Rose 8 still stops on a dime and holds the floor like a grudge (word, Rakim). Dust was barely an issue because the pattern is wide and pushes any debris out and off the sole to keep you ripping.
Traction was really, really good. Very squeaky and very hard bite. I haven't slipped yet, and I have played on dusty courts.

The support comes from the heel counter, outrigger, and the ankle collar. Ticks all the boxes!

Overall a great fitting shoe even for me as a wide-footer.
Once laced up I felt secure.

I found the traction to be first class in every regard.

I think the Kobe AD Mid is the best Kobe shoe out right now! Better than the NXT or the regular AD.

Overall, the Kobe AD Mid is a solid performer with phenomenal traction, nice cushioning and solid support. The suede material is a little too stiff for my liking, but hopefully, future releases with a Jacquard or Flyknit upper will fix this issue.
The Kobe AD is an amazing performer but I just wish they had used a different upper material.
I think the Kobe AD Mid is an excellent all-around performer on the court. Not surprisingly, it’s one of my top five for the year due to its great overall performance.
The Kobe AD Mid is a beautiful and comfortable shoe that unfortunately suffers from bad ventilation and a small amount of heel slippage. Otherwise, I really like this shoe!

This shoe feels very different than any other Kobe shoe I ever played in. It provides less responsiveness and court feel than other Kobes. It seems like after his retirement, Kobe wants a little more cushioning and a more "old school" vibe from his shoes.
This is a very well performing shoe but there are no standout features. Great pickup for Kobe fans, but there are cheaper shoes that perform just as well.
The shoe plays and performs really well. Traction was awesome and the cushion was solid — especially for guards. Ventilation and material quality are where the Kobe AD Mid’s could improve.
The Kobe AD Mid is a beautiful shoe. The only real complaint I have is with the lacing system digging into my foot.

Traction was good and cushion was good, but it bottomed out quickly and hurt my feet on heavier impacts. The materials are really stiff and thick, and they gave me blisters. The ankle support was also really bad. If you're gonna buy Kobe's, get a nicer pair, not these.
The perfect outdoor shoe, will last ages unless you get gum rubber or translucent outsole
Awesome shoe, wore down pretty quickly when played outdoors but indoors it was flawless

The traction is beastly!
The traction is excellent and just outside the elite group.
This traction is beastly!

A budget model that performs like a top-tier model. Traction is amazing, the cushion is okay, materials are really nice and they fit me very well. I think this is one of the best-performing Under Armour shoes out right now!
Overall, this is a great shoe that will work for every type of player. Good job Under Armour!
Overall, the Drive 4 is a decent, serviceable shoe — nothing except traction really stands out, yet the shoe is good for players at all positions.
This shoe is for the every day, every position player and it is a solid performer. If you require more cushion like myself, then you may have to look elsewhere.

The Under Armour Drive 4 is a solid hoops shoe for a low-budget price. I like them more than the Steph Curry 3 Zero. They feel lighter, are more flexible and the traction is on point. The cushioning is not a strong point but is still fairly good.

The Drive 4 has some things going for it (traction) and then there are some things that need work (fit and materials). If you’re someone who plays low to the ground, prefers a stable ride and has a wide foot, these are going to be great for you.
Herringbone pattern is so good for outdoor use. Traction is amazing but cushion is hard especially forefoot. Good for wide footers. It is not fit to me.
The traction is really, really nice.
Herringbone traction held up on every surface I played on.
The traction is going to bite and not let go.
The traction on the UA Drive 4 is bonkers.
The traction grips really, really well and is one of the strong points of these shoes.
The rubber compound could’ve been a little tackier but that didn’t keep these from working on virtually every floor condition you can think of.

The bootie-style upper and internal heel counter keep your feet locked down. Overall, the support is great and almost as good as the traction!
Support is really good and makes the shoe safe for any position.
The shoe does a pretty decent job in terms of handling itself on-court.
Support and lockdown are pretty solid, containment is good.

I really enjoyed the fit.
Nothing that makes the shoe unplayable. There are just better options if fit is your number one priority.

Outside of the lacking cushioning the Jordan Super.Fly 2017 is so close to being perfect it’s kind of scary,

The Jordan Super.Fly 2017 was an absolute delight to ball in.  If you’re okay with the firmness of React cushioning and enjoy a low profile on-court ride, this has you covered with traction, lockdown, and stability.

Crazy good performance, looks dope, premium materials. Overall, an amazing shoe, get it!

The adidas Crazy Explosive 2017 Primeknit is a great shoe! I love this thing like crazy and it is by far my favorite hoop shoe of 2017 so far. It’s number one in my rotation and I’m pretty sure it will be in many of yours as well.

Improved fit and killer cushioning should put the Crazy Explosive 2017 PK on everyone’s radar this year if you play basketball. Grab this shoe if you need traction for indoor courts, #Boostislife cushioning, a locked-in fit, and quick support.
Feels like playing in a sock with good traction and Boost cushioning!
Great shoe! If you can - get the solid rubber version as it offers slightly improved traction.
I am really happy with the Crazy Explosive 2017. Crazy comfortable, great cushioning and traction.

I think most players will enjoy the Crazy Explosive 2017 because it does everything well if not great and really gives the player an excellent one to one fit with a low to ground yet well cushioned ride.

I prefer the 2016 version over the Crazy Explosive 2017. The traction is identical, cushioning is a lot firmer and less plush, lockdown and support are a little better and the materials are a lot stiffer and less comfortable. Overall, still a very solid shoe.
THIS SHOES IS A BEAST! it's good for outdoors and indoors! It doesn't really pick up dust easily
Traction bites hard and it's a very cushiony shoe. Would buy if you can find any.
Traction is really good!
Traction is phenomenal on clean as well as dusty courts.
On clean, indoor courts, enjoy. Seriously, for that surface, this is one of the top patterns, perhaps ever.
I didn't have any problems with the traction, performs really well.
The solid rubber works really well and picks up less dust than the translucent version.
The traction gets the job done. I didn't have to wipe a lot, even on dustier courts.
Works great on clean floors but requires a fair amount of wiping on dusty floors.
The traction is not the best compared to other shoes, but it is still solid. Excellent on clean courts, but on dusty courts you will need to wipe a lot.
Caged full-length boost is really plush. Overall an amazing setup, maybe the best available.
The cushion is beast-mode. I love it!
2017 PK is quicker on-foot and on-court than the 2016 with the same great impact protection and energy return.
Boost Cushioning is really nice!
You can't go wrong with full-length boost.
Boost is just incredible. Comfortable, super responsive and great court feel - how is that even possible?
The set up feels ever so slightly firmer than last year’s which is great for me
Boost feels really stiff compared to the last years model.
Forged Primeknit is a little stiff in the beginning but gets really soft after breaking in.  Materials are great and super premium, but a little too stiff for my liking.
I preferred the materials of the previous Crazy Explosive model, but overall, I still love this setup.
The knit is flexible and form-fitting and doesn’t stretch too much while playing, which is great.
Forged PrimeKnit is thicker and provides more support than last years thinner PrimeKnit.
PrimeKnit upper is very comfortable and looks great.
Doesn't feel as soft or flexible as last years. No issues here for me but it takes a few runs to get the upper to break in.
Forged PrimeKnit is a lot more stiff and solid compared to the 2016 version.
No heel slippage, very good lockdown and support.
Support was great.
The wide forefoot keeps you upright on lateral moves. The cage on the lateral side keeps the foot contained over the footbed, and the stiffer knit holds true on push-offs and plants.
Big heel counter, no side-to-side movement and lateral outrigger that provides additional stability.
Even though the PrimeKnit is backed by TPU, the upper is not as supportive as I'd like it to be.
Stability is once again excellent on the Crazy Explosive thanks a large flat outsole, low ride and infinity shank.
Support and lockdown is really good.
The snug fit is really, really nice.
This year we now have five eyelets and everything from the forefoot to heel was contained nicely so I had no issues.
Perfect. Nothing else should be said!
The 1:1 fit of the one piece bootie is super nice.
The fit is super comfortable because of the soft PrimeKnit upper. One of the most comfortable shoes I ever played in!
The fit on the CE 17 is fantastic and really gives a one to one sock like feel.
Fit is really comfortable except in one location. The TPU outrigger on the lateral side caused a lot of pain in my pinkie toe.
Durability might be better compared to last year, but I still don't think it will be good outdoors.
I think the solid rubber will hold up outdoors.
The Crazy Explosive is still prone to peeling and wear so not really recommended for outdoor use.
Slightly narrow, but not very narrow.
Wide footers should go up half a size maybe even a full size because these run tight.
This is one Adidas shoe that fits true to size
Wide footers should go up half a size maybe even a full size because these run tight.
This shoe is pretty nice and works well for guards who need a responsive shoe. Feels a little like a low-top Kyrie 2 with nicer materials and worse traction.
Overall this is a solid shoe that has signature model-like qualities at a retail price of $100 - you can't really beat that!
Overall, this is a pretty good shoe. Nothing crazy, but very good value for the money!
While the Nike Zoom Shift is aesthetically pleasing, the inconsistent traction and the brick-like cushion makes the shoe very unpleasant on-court.
The traction was good and worked fairly well on dusty courts.
The outsole wraps around the side of the shoe similar to the Kyrie 3.
On clean courts you are alright, but on dusty courts you are slipping all time.
Traction is very inconsistent and very frustrating.
The cushioning is really stiff and responsive, but impact protection is minimal.
Forefoot Zoom similar to the PG1.

Decent materials for a budget model.
The lightweight mesh upper is a good combination of comfort and breathability.
The materials are very breathable and durable.
he best features of the Nike Zoom Shift are its materials.

The support is probably the best feature of this shoe.
The support mainly comes from the fit.

There is no getting out of the shoe until you take them off.

I recommend going true to size.
I recommend going a size up.
Overall, the Nike Lebron Soldier 11 is the bomb, I love it! I have no complaints about it whatsoever. This shoe jumped up to #2 on my rotation, that's how much I liked it.

While traction could still use a little bit of work, the cushion is immensely better than the last go-around. Suitable for every position on the floor and a great option for players than want a little bit of everything with their on-court shoes.

A well-rounded shoe that provides a ton of support and lockdown. Traction is decent. Not recommended for shifty guards because it feels a little bulky, but a very good shoe for bigger players who value impact protection, lockdown and support.
Although the Soldier XI doesn’t do anything extremely well, it’s a very solid shoe all the way around.

The LeBron Soldier 11 in many ways is “just” the LeBron Soldier 10.1. That’s really not a bad thing though, as the Soldier 10 was a great shoe, and the 11 improves on almost every aspect of its design with very minimal compromise.
Good for what it does, doesn't quite get the Kick Genius stamp of approval but definitely gets the job done. The best Lebron Soldier I ever played in for sure.

The Nike LeBron Soldier 11 is a very versatile sneaker. Any guard or slashing forward will find something that they like. It is a solid option both indoors and on the black top, yet it isn’t quite “elite.” Had Nike went all out on the cushioning and made it a little more stable, it would have easily been a top-tier performer.

It's a really, really solid shoe. I loved the cushioning and responsiveness, the support and lockdown were really solid, but traction was very inconsistent. Not my go-to shoes but definitely in the rotation.

this shoe has the best support I've probably ever played in. The cushion is there but felt very little. the traction in one word is well, inconsistent. On a dusty court you're slipping and sliding, and on a clean court you either have amazing grip or you're still slipping. This shoe is a bit bulky and I recommend for larger forwards or wing players.
Great for a bouncy wing. Have had 3 pair of these for 5+ years and they are all in great shape with no issues, except velcro failing.
Amazing shoes… have beautiful strap… confortable..
After the shoes broke in the traction was really awesome.
While the traction on the Nike LeBron Soldier 11 isn’t bad, it isn’t as good as it should be.
Traction is very nice on clean courts, but picks up a fair amount of dust.
It has a surprising bite and held up even on dusty floors without much wiping at all.
The traction of the Soldier 11, on the other had, is actually good. You’ll have to swipe occasionally, like almost every shoe, but after a very brief break-in period, the grip was squeaky and secure.
If you are in dustier setting your are going to slide all over the place. On clean courts traction is really good.
The traction on the LeBron Soldier 11 is surprisingly solid but not very consistent.
The traction was pretty inconsistent. Good on clean courts, but horrible on really dusty courts. Even Lebron slipped in these during the finals.
Protruding Nike Zoom Units in the forefoot and heel felt amazing.
The Zoom Air units are pretty damn big which means impact protection is solid overall.
You get a ton of response because the cushion is pretty firm.
There is a decent amount of bounce to the Zoom but still not as lively as my standard, the Soldier VI.
The dual-Zoom bag setup is better implemented than in the Soldier 10 and provides a noticeable improvement.
Zoom Air in both the heel and forefoot performs admirably - it just would have been so much better with full-length Zoom.
The cushion is pretty standard but responsiveness is great.
Materials look so nice, I don't even want to hoop in these. But breathability is not existent.
Materials offer the feeling of wearing a knit/woven upper but with a bit more strength.
Materials feel better than in the Soldier 10 but are still relatively cheap.
Nothing fancy, just plain old mesh.
The  suede overlay of the "premium” version of the LeBron Soldier 11 is too nice to pass up.
The materials are nothing special. The upper is soft and comfortable but breathability is a problem
Is the shoe’s fit supportive enough without laces being involved? Yes, at least for me.
The upper is very supportive and doesn't stretch, lateral support is great and ankle support is decent too.
Thanks to a low-to-the-ground ride, flat outsole and double outrigger the Lebron Soldier is very stable and supportive.
Sculpted collar padding, along with the external heel counter and forefoot outriggers, combine to create confidence in the shoe’s stability.
The four straps gave me extra confidence while recovering from an ankle sprain.
This is the first time that I’ve ever felt like a LeBron sneaker needed more support.
Lockdown is great. At times I felt a little wobbly because of the narrow base, but overall I didn't have any problems with support.
The shoes are a little hard to get on, lockdown on the shoe was good and once the materials are broke in a bit things started to feel secure.
Once you get your feet in, the straps lock down you feet really right, I love it!
I had no movement side to side or front to back, no heel slip, well done Nike!
The Soldier 11 is essentially a sock with some straps. But similar to the Soldier 10, it actually fits well.
Out of the box these shoes have an extremely snug but comfortable fit. As time goes on the materials will soften up and you end up with a pillowy experience that feels just a bit soft.
The overall comfort of the Soldier 11 is definitely an improvement over the Soldier 10 and feels pretty nice.
The rubber is pretty hard, so outdoor play should be okay.
Doesn't feel as wide as previous Soldier Models.
Go true to size.
True to size for everyone.
Overall the shoe is very similar to the KD 9. I like the firmer cushioning, the soft and flexible upper, but the support could be better.
The KD10 is a great shoe overall but there are some downfalls like the lacking of lateral support.

I like the shoe a lot! If you are not looking to do heavy lateral cuts or be really shifty then this is a great shoe! Very comfortable fit and great cushion make these perfect when you want to give your legs some extra comfort.

Compared to the KD9, the Zoom is toned down, for good and bad. The materials are definitely improved. The looks — let’s face it, this is a beautiful shoe. But the traction slid a little and the overall playability seemed a step back from the KD9.
The KD10 just misses being a great shoe due to minor flaws in construction and traction — but they don’t deter it from being a good performance shoe.
Overall, the KD10 is a decent shoe, it just not as good as the KD9.
Overall, this is a good shoe. Unfortunately, traction and support keep it from being great.
The Nike KD 9 was an amazing shoe. The Nike KD 10 was almost an amazing shoe. It looks amazing, but it suffered in a few areas due to the bold new design.
Overall the KD 10 performs solid in all categories. There is nothing phenomenal but on the flip side there is also nothing bad.

The Nike KD10 was definitely not my favourite shoe, but it definitely wasn’t the worst. It is mostly suitable for forwards. The traction was decent on a clean court, but on dust, it was very sloppy. The cushion was okay, but it didn’t have all too much court feel. I also found the shoe a little stiff. The support was very sloppy tho, and my foot would always slide out the footbed. Ankle support wasn’t great either. The materials were okay and a little breathable, but the laces were inconvenient.
I think the cushioning is very good but has little durability because it broke very easy, and this didn’t only happened to me, my friends happened too.
Overall, traction is pretty solid.
I absolutely love the traction!
Nothing incredible or groundbreaking but traction is good.
I never experienced any straight slipping in moves or game play, but traction didn't bite the way I like it.
While the outsole design did provide multi-directional coverage, the grooves picked up dust — especially on the forefoot and heel points
The traction is inconsistent, works well on clean courts, but on dusty courts, you will need to wipe a lot.
The traction is just okay. On dusty courts, I was sliding a lot.
The traction on both of my KD 10s just didn’t work out for me.
The traction is solid.
Cushioning is a bit more firm compared to the KD9, but I like the more responsive setup.
Springy is the word that comes to mind.
Good impact protection, super bouncy, great heel to toe transition but you lose a little court feel.
This is the way Nike Zoom should feel, all day, every day.
Full-length Articulated Max Zoom Air. The ride was responsive without taking away from court feel but there is also plenty of impact protection
This time the cushioning is a bit firmer compared to the KD9.
Full-length Zoom - but it doesn't feel anything like the KD9. This time the cushion is firmer and more responsive.
The cushion offers the best impact protection Nike currently has available.
Max cushioning of full length zoom, but I prefer more court feel.
Flyknit upper is super soft and flexible
The reinforced FlyKnit is very comfortable.
Flyknit materials are very premium, top notch!
Soft, pliable, comfy, and form-fitting, the upper of the KD is what the future of Flyknit in basketball should be.
Flyknit materials are everything when done correctly and here, from heel to forefoot, it’s Flyknit errrry-thang!
Materials work, but I liked the KD9 materials much better.
The full FlyKnit upper feels amazing.
I love the materials that were used on the Nike KD 10, I just don’t love how they performed.

The upper material is too soft and doesn't provide enough lateral support.

There are no serious structures to prevent rollover, just a good fit, wide base, and solid heel counter.
I had an issue with the shoe: one of my lace loops ripped. Apart from that, the containment was decent.

Despite the base of the shoe being a solid platform, it just wasn’t enough to say these are cutting it in the support department.
Way easier to put the shoe on compared to the KD 9.
The foot is held in nicely.

The fit of the shoe is fine but intense lateral cuts and heavy rotations on-court may cause some instabilities.
If you pull the laces really tight, the fit is pretty good.

I would recommend to go half a size down.

Is the Curry 3ZER0 leaps and bounds better than the Curry 3? No. However, the cushion feels more refined and offers a better balance between stability and protection.  If you’re a guard or a shooter and plan on trying out the Curry 3ZER0 I think you’ll be pleasantly surprised.

Out of the three Curry models released this year, I’d put the Low first, the 3Zero slightly behind at second and then the Mid. The Curry 3 Zero is a more minimal shoe that doesn't rely on bells and whistles or tech mumbo-jumbo, which I personally enjoy.

For a $120 this is not a bad shoe! Really good on-court performer and I like the fit much better compared to the original Curry 3. I just wish they hadn't downgraded the material from Threadborne to Mesh.
The SC 3Zero is a solid second line shoe. Overall, I wasn't a big fan of the new cushioning setup and the inconsistent traction. However, I did like the improved ankle support.
Just like the Curry 3, nothing special. I wasn't happy with the fit and the traction. Let's hope for an improved Curry 4.
These shoes I got were previously owned,but the lock down and outrigger was something else as you never have to worry about rolling your ankle while playing basketball in them.
Herringbone and solid rubber — the things that make for some beastly traction no matter the court condition.
Great on clean floors but will require wiping when dusty.
Traction is very good on clean or dusty courts.
On clean courts you are ready to go, on mildly dusty courts you will need to wipe from time to time.
Traction on clean courts is really good, but the shoe is a real dust magnet.
If you wanted a cushion that balances stability and comfort then this is the setup for you.

Overall there is no real difference in cushioning so if you didn’t like the cushioning on the 2.5 or 3, you won’t like these either.  Personally, I find these work well for me and my game but to each their own.
Micro-G cushion is a lot more forgiving than the firmer Curry 3 Charged cushioning.
The cushioning setup is a little stiffer than the original Curry 3. I personally wasn't a fan and would have liked a little more bounce.
The cushioning is very, very stiff. The insole is nice, impact protection is decent.
This setup is very durable and worked just fine on-court. However, some break-in time is required.

Materials are pretty basic.
Lightweight, flexible and breathable materials.
After a few days, the materials become soft and comfortable.
The shoe’s tooling sits wide and stable — built in outrigger included.
Lockdown is perfectly fine and stability is very good as is with a contoured forefoot and flat outsole.
The lockdown is crazy good thanks to the adjustable heel sleeve.
The adjustable heel provides great ankle support and works great for ankle brace wearers.
Very good lockdown, strong upper materials, good support.
Comfortable fit, even when wearing an ankle brace.
Less puffy padding makes the Curry 3Zero less bulky than the Curry 3.
The fit is a huge improvement over the Curry 3.
Not as comfortable as the original Curry 3. They feel really stiff in the beginning but get more comfortable after a while.

Outdoor use should be okay.

Go down half a size.

The ANTA KT Outdoor 2 Low is a very good hoop shoe that offers a little bit of everything — court feel, semi-plush cushioning, durable traction that works on a variety of surfaces, and materials that are very much in line with what other brands are offering.

The Anta KT Outdoor 2 Low is a solid shoe. It's very light, has good impact protection and superb traction. I highly recommend this shoe for hoopers who love to play in both indoor and outdoor courts.
I was really impressed with this shoes, especially at $80! This will be my go-to outdoor shoe.
This is an outdoor specific outsole that works wonders indoors and outdoors.
I think the traction is the best feature of this shoe. Works great indoors and outdoors.
On a clean court, traction is great. Unfortunately, they pick up dust very fast.
Not only is the cushion comfortable but it does a good job of absorbing impact.
Nice cushioning in the heel, but I wished there was more in the forefoot.
The cushion is very soft and bouncy with great impact protection.
Mesh and synthetics are used on the ANTA KT Outdoor 2 Low which is a significant improvement over the entirely fuse-based KT Outdoor 1.
Mesh can be found in the forefoot and synthetic leather on the heel and ankle area. Not innovative at all - but gets the job done!
Materials are soft, but they feel really cheap.
Overall support in the KT Outdoor 2 Low is solid.
The wide base offers great lateral stability.
There is a small amount of heel slip at times.
For outdoor use it's very, very good.

I think this is a very good shoe. Great traction, nice materials and an outstanding fit (for narrow feet). This is a BIG upgrade over the original Kobe AD
The NXT version of the Kobe A.D. has much more in common with the Kobe 11 than with the ori
It is just a well-rounded performer with great traction, fun cushioning, excellent fit and stability and decent containment. These edge out the Curry 3 Low for my favorite of 2017.
For $200 this shoe is a no-go. Disregarding the price, the Kobe AD NXT is a really good performer.

The Kobe AD NXT has some exciting high points and I truly enjoyed playing in these thanks to the fantastic upper comfort. Unfortunately, at $200 this is the most expensive basketball shoe model in the 2017 Nike lineup. There are far better values out there.
I really enjoyed the traction.
The traction had no issues on any surface no matter the condition.
I had no issues at all with the NXT traction, well done Nike!
Traction bites really hard on clean courts. On dusty courts, you will need to wipe a lot.
From game one, the Kobe A.D. NXT’s traction was top-notch.
I was very happy with the traction.
Lunarlon midsole with a Nike Zoom unit in the heel - one of my favorite setups.
The large volume heel Zoom Air unit coupled with a Lunarlon midsole works very well.
I could feel the heel Zoom and Lunarlon from the get-go. Well done Nike!
Heel Zoom unit provides you with decent impact protection.
The Zoom bag provided plenty of impact protection, but Lunarlon quickly lost a lot of its initial cushioning.
I thought the cushioning setup was pretty good on these. A great balance between cushioning and court feel.
A mixture of mesh and knit provides the best Nike has to offer.
The shoe is made out of a mesh textile build that is very breathable.
No issues here but for $200 you’d think you’d get all Flyknit.
The materials are very nice and super soft from the get-go.
You sit low to the ground so stability is great while the overall containment (from the fit) is wonderful.
Overall, I really liked the mobility of wearing a low without any fear or turning my ankle.
Support is very good.
Great heel lockdown and two subtle outriggers help the shoe to excel in this area.
I don't think there is another shoe that will fit as great as this one.
For those that enjoy that really snug feeling on-foot then you’ll likely enjoy the hell out of these.
I had no movement side to side and zero heel slip. I really enjoyed the one to one fit with the NXT.
The new lacing system is a no-go. You can't really get it to securely lock down your forefoot.

The new lacing system not only sounds great on paper but also actually works. The feel of the NXT’s upper is second to none. I wasn’t able to achieve a fit quite as snug as with traditional lacing systems, but there was still enough support that the tradeoff was well worth it in terms of comfort.
I had a little heel slippage, the lockdown was fine and the shoes were really comfortable.
Outdoor use is not recommended.
Wide footers can go up half a size.
The fit is rather narrow similar to other Kobe models.
They are a little narrow.
These fit true to size lengthwise.
